(2) It shall be unlawful for a wine specialty shop to sell or have on the premises spirituous liquors or packaged malt beverages. (3) A wine specialty shop shall be allowed to sell growlers containing craft draft beer, as long as they follow provisions set forth in section 6-30 of this chapter. (4) Shall be allowed to serve craft draft beers by the glass for consumption on the premises only during the same hours as are permitted in subsection 6-20(c) under this chapter for the sale of "malt beverages and wine packaged sales." Packaged sales of craft draft beers other than craft draft beer growlers is prohibited. Malt beverages fees shall apply for consumption on the premises of craft draft beers. (5) Only the licensee or an employee shall dispense craft/draft beers from a tap. Free samples of wine or craft draft beers shall not exceed one and a half ounces nor shall any one individual be offered more than three samples within a calendar day. (6) Sampling or tasting of wine or craft draft beers is only permitted within the designated portion of the premises. (b) A retail establishment operating as a wine specialty shop shall provide the city clerk's office, at the time of alcohol license renewal, a statement prepared by licensee's bookkeeper or accountant of the gross sales of the business for the preceding calendar year. The statement shall include the total gross sales for the establishment and document the percentage of sales in dollars attributed to consumption on the premises as compared to package sales and other general merchandise sales. Copies of the state sales tax returns for the same period shall be attached to the statement. The statement must be properly notarized and certified to be true and correct by the licensee or his/her agent under penalty of law, and shall accompany the renewal license fee payment on or before December 31, of each year. The city reserves the right to require, for any reasons deemed necessary by the city, a certified audit for sales of wine. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000; Ord. No. 2011-22, § 1, 9-1-2011; Ord. No. 2013-11, § 1, 4-18-2013; Ord. No. 2013-20, § 1, 5-16-2013) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 6-2. - License required. It shall be unlawful for any malt beverage, wine, spirituous liquor or any other alcoholic beverage to be stored, delivered, sold or manufactured in the city, except under a license issued pursuant to this chapter, and then only for the specific beverage and manner of sale provided in such license. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-3. - Conflicting provisions. The requirements of this chapter shall be in addition to any other requirements for business licenses under this Code, and if other provisions of this Code conflict with this chapter, this chapter shall control. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-4. - Fees. (a) Licenses which may be issued under this chapter, and the alcoholic beverage license fees, shall be as follows: (1) Manufacturing: a. Malt beverages ..... $550.00 b. Wine ..... 550.00 c. Spirituous liquors ..... 3,330.00 (2) Wholesale: a. Malt beverages ..... 100.00 b. Wine ..... 100.00 c. Spirituous liquors ..... 1,650.00 (3) Retail package: a. Malt beverages ..... 400.00 b. Wine ..... 400.00 c. Spirituous liquors ..... 1,720.00 d. Sunday sales ..... 270.00 (4) Consumption on the premises: a. Malt beverages ..... 500.00 b. Wine ..... 500.00 c. Spirituous liquors ..... 2,625.00 d. Sunday sales ..... 650.00; or e. Growlers (for craft draft beers only, for purchase and consumption off premises) ..... 200.00 (per calendar or any portion of a calendar year) (5) Wine specialty shop (add on to package license only): a. Wine ..... 300.00 b. Growlers (for craft beers only) ..... 200.00 (per calendar or any portion of a calendar year) c. Craft draft beers ..... 500.00 (6) Any combination of sales listed in this section at the same location, provided, no retail or wholesale licensee shall hold any consumption on the premises license for the same location. (7) Any new license issued before July 1 shall not be subject to proration. Any new license issued on or after July 1 shall be subject to half the annual license fee without further proration. (b) If the wholesale dealer's principal place of business is located within the city, the city will levy a license fee in accordance with the classification into which the applicant falls. In addition to the general occupation tax, the wholesale dealer shall also pay a $100.00 processing fee to cover the expenses of investigation and processing. Permit applications of wholesale dealers located within the city shall be approved by the mayor and board of aldermen. If the wholesale dealer delivers alcoholic beverages based on orders previously taken, no license fee shall be required, but the wholesaler shall be required to register with the business license manager, on a form prescribed by the city, prior to delivery of any alcoholic beverages. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000; Ord. No. 2011-22, § 1, 9-1-2011; Ord. No. 2011-26, § 1, 11-17-2011; Ord. No. 2012-14, § 1, 7-5-2012; Ord. No. 2013-11, § 2, 4-18-2013; Ord. No. 2013-20, § 2, 5-16-2013; Ord. No. 2016-24, § 1, 6-16-2016) Sec. 6-5. - State registration required. (a) City alcoholic beverage licenses shall not become effective until each business which is required to obtain an alcohol license from the state has registered with the state and is in good standing with the state, or has received such license from the state. (b) At the time a new applicant submits an alcoholic beverage license application to the city, a copy of the state license application and/or forms shall be required for processing. (c) New applicants shall be required to submit to the city a copy or proof of the state license for the alcohol license establishment immediately upon receipt of the state license and no later than 45 days after receiving a city license. (d) Renewal licensees shall be required to submit to the city a copy or proof of the current state license for the alcohol license establishment by January 31 of each year. (e) The city may issue an alcoholic beverage license to an alcohol license establishment at the time a background check is made and fees are paid for renewal of such a license. However, a copy and/or proof of the current state license must be submitted annually by the licensee in order for the city alcoholic beverage license to remain in effect. The city shall indicate on the alcoholic beverage license certificate that, "This license is invalid without the state alcohol license, as per Section 6-5 of the City of Acworth, Georgia, Code of Ordinances." (f) The alcoholic beverage license shall be subject to revocation in the event the applicant does not submit to the city a copy and/or proof of the state license in a timely manner as per section 6-5(c) and (d). (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000; Ord. No. 2009-14, § 1, 10-15-2009; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 2, 11-5-2009) Sec. 6-6. - Time limits on opening and continuing business. (a) All businesses licensed pursuant to this chapter must open for business within 90 days after the issuance of such city license. Failure to open for business within such 90-day period of time shall constitute a forfeiture and cancellation of the issued license, and no refund of the license fees or business taxes shall be made. Any applicant unable to comply with the time limit of this subsection may make written request to the city manager for an extension of such time limit, not to exceed 90 days; and the mayor and board of aldermen, at their discretion, may grant or deny such request. (b) Any license issued under this chapter shall automatically be null and void where the licensed business has not operated or been open to the public for six consecutive months. Any applicant unable to comply with the time limit of this subsection may make written request to the mayor and board of aldermen for an extension of such time limit, not to exceed 90 days; and the mayor and board of aldermen, at their discretion, may grant or deny such request. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-7. - Prohibited interests. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person within the city, who has any direct financial interest in a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages at wholesale, to hold any other license or an interest in any other license under the terms of this chapter, unless otherwise allowed by state law. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person related within the first degree of relationship or affinity under civil law to any wholesale licensee or employee of such licensee, or any person with any interest in such licensee, to hold any other license or an interest in any other license issued under this chapter, unless otherwise allowed by state law. (c) No elected or full-time appointed official of the city, or any person related within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity under civil law to such an official of the city, shall own any interest in any license issued under this chapter, unless one of the following conditions shall be met: (1) The interest was obtained prior to election or appointment to office; (2) The interest is declared in writing at the time the application for such license is made, and the elected or full-time appointed official shall not participate in official action or consideration of the license; or (3) The interest obtained in an ongoing business holding a license is declared in writing at the time of the acquisition and filed with the city clerk. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-8. - New license applications. The provisions of this Code relating to general business licensing shall apply to alcoholic beverage licenses within the city, in addition to the following: (1) All applications for new licenses under this chapter shall be accompanied by a payment, in cash or by certified check, for all of the minimum fees and business taxes provided for in this Code for the classification into which the applicant falls. (2) Each application for a malt beverage, wine or spirituous liquor license, whether manufacturing, wholesale, retail package or consumption on the premises, shall include a nonrefundable $200.00 alcoholic beverage processing fee to cover the expenses of advertising, investigation and processing of the application. All applications shall be subject to approval by the mayor and board of aldermen. (3) The city application shall contain a photostatic or similar copy of all the appropriate state applications and forms, as well as a city supplemental application form provided by the city, and the following: a. A legal description of the property upon which the premises to be licensed are located; b. A current photograph of the applicant; c. Fingerprints of the applicant which shall be taken by the police department. (4) The application shall also contain a form of oath providing that the information disclosed in the application is true and correct, and further providing that the applicant will abide by, observe and conduct his business according to the rules and regulations prescribed by the city, the acts of the general assembly, known as the Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Laws And Regulations, 1986 edition, as amended, and the rules and regulations of the state department of revenue in respect thereto. The oath shall be taken by the applicant and the agent in charge of the establishment, if different from or additional to the applicant, and the true owners of the establishment. (5) Any false statement or material misrepresentation in any application under this chapter shall be grounds for the revocation of any license granted under this chapter. (6) The application shall be in compliance with the city zoning ordinance. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-8.1. - Mandatory training. (a) Effective January 1, 2015, all new businesses at locations in the City of Acworth (Cobb County) where an alcoholic beverage license has not previously been issued, where there is a change of ownership of the alcoholic beverage license, or where there is any change of licensee and the new licensee has not previously attended a responsible alcohol sales and service policy workshop, applicant/licensee will be required to attend a certified workshop as approved by the city clerk. The applicant/licensee shall attend said workshop, at their own expense, prior to the issuance of any alcoholic beverage license. The applicant/licensee shall present a certificate of completion of an alcohol sales and service policy workshop prior to the submission of an alcoholic beverage license application, however, if an applicant/licensee has been previously certified by an approved vendor selected by the city clerk, a new certificate shall not be required. (b) Effective November 1, 2015, the provisions of this section shall apply to renewal applications. Under no circumstances shall the workshop provision be waived. It shall be the responsibility for all certified applicants/licensees to train their employees including, but not limited to, alcohol servers and managers. (c) In the event of revocation or suspension of an alcoholic beverage license, instructors, trainers, or any persons associated with or employed by approved certification vendors shall not appear before the city manager or board of aldermen as a representative, attorney, advocate, or witness for any applicant/licensee. (Ord. No. 2014-26, § 1, 11-20-2014) Sec. 6-9. - Residency required; registered agents. (a) All applicants for licenses under this chapter shall be bona fide residents of the United States at the time of the filing of the application, and shall remain a bona fide resident during all times that the license, and any renewal of such license, is in effect. All applicants, if a natural person, all managers designated as such, and all registered agents nominated pursuant to this section shall be at least 21 years of age. (b) All applications for licenses under this chapter shall nominate and name in the application one or more residents of the State of Georgia as the registered agent and representative of the applicant to receive all communications, notices, services or process or other papers or documents on behalf of the applicant in connection with any matter arising out of or connected with the issuance, holding, suspension, revocation or other action with respect to any city license. The applicant for a license shall give the mailing address of such registered agent, and the mailing to any registered agent at such address of any notice required to be given under this chapter or any other law shall be deemed as sufficient notice to the applicant/licensee. (c) The registered agent shall be a representative of the licensee, and must be approved by the city manager. The police department shall perform a background check and such record shall be placed on file with the city clerk's office. The mayor and board of aldermen shall refuse to approve any registered agent who is not a bona fide resident of the United States and a resident of the State of Georgia, or who has been convicted, within the five years preceding his nomination, of any felony of any kind, any misdemeanor relating to an alcoholic beverage business or any state law or county or municipal ordinance violation relating to any alcoholic beverage business. (d) If any registered agent shall cease to be a representative of the licensee, shall cease to be a resident of the United States and the State of Georgia, or in any manner ceases to meet the requirements of subsection (c) of this section, the licensee shall notify the city clerk in writing of such event, and shall nominate a new registered agent within three days after such event occurs. Such new registered agent shall meet the requirements of subsection (b) and (c) of this section, and must be approved by the city manager. The city shall charge a fee of $30.00 for a change of the licensee's registered agent; provided, however, that if the licensee fails to notify the city and nominate a new registered agent within such three-day period, then the city may charge a fee of $50.00 for a change of the licensee's registered agent and/or revoke the licensee's license. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000; Ord. No. 2005-22, 5-5-2005; Ord. No. 2015-06, § 1, 5-7-2015) Sec. 6-10. - Preliminary approval required; nonpayment of taxes; additional investigations and interviews; processing time limit. (a) The mayor and board of aldermen shall cause an inquiry to be made into the city tax records to determine if an applicant for a license under this chapter, or other parties with interest in such application, has any outstanding taxes or special assessments that are delinquent against his property or any other moneys owing to the city. No license under this chapter shall be issued or renewed until such debts are paid in full. (b) All applications for licenses under this chapter shall be reviewed by the chief of police or his designee as a condition to action on and issuance of a license by the mayor and board of aldermen. If the police department determines that the application is not in order, in view of the requirements of federal or state law or this Code and any police department investigation, the city manager shall then notify the applicant of the reasons for such decision, and forward a recommendation of license denial to the mayor and board of aldermen. (c) All applicants for licenses under this chapter shall furnish all reasonable data, information and records requested of such applicants by the city, and failure to furnish such data, information, contracts, documents, financial statements and other records within 30 days of the request for such material shall automatically serve to dismiss the license application. (d) The police department may require, in addition to the licensee, fingerprinting and a background investigation of any person interested in the license application, including any person with a financial interest, such as stockholders, partners or employees, and any sibling of any person with a financial interest, and the nominated registered agent of any corporate applicant. Should the applicant fail to produce such persons within 30 days of the request, the police department shall recommend denial of the application. (e) By filing an application for a license under this chapter, the applicant agrees to produce for interview any person requested by the police department and considered as being important in the ascertainment of the facts relative to such license. The failure to produce such persons within 30 days after being requested to do so may result in a denial of the application by the police department. (f) The city may require 45 days for processing any application for a license under this chapter. For investigative purposes and according to the licensee's compliance, the chief of police may extend the processing period up to an additional 15 days if the police chief shall deem such extension necessary. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-11. - Posting of sign on premises; notice of board of alderman meeting on application. An applicant for a license under this chapter shall cause to be placed upon the location of the premises proposed to be licensed, signs of a size, number and form prescribed by the city manager, stating the names of the owners of such premises, and the address of the applicant, type of license applied for, business name and location applied for, and the time, date and location of the board of aldermen meeting on the application. Such signs shall be posted at the location within a two-week period immediately preceding the meeting date of the board of aldermen. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-12. - Change of location. Any business taxable under this chapter which moves from one location in the city to another shall notify the office of the city clerk in writing of the move and the new address on a form provided by the business license department. Such business shall be considered a new applicant, and shall be subject to the requirements of section 6-8. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-13. - Transfer of ownership. (a) The transfer of ownership of an alcoholic beverage license shall be considered in the same manner as the termination of the business and the establishment of a new business. If the owner of an alcoholic beverage license desires to transfer such license, or if any interest in the business for which the license was issued is sold or otherwise transferred, the purchaser or transferee of such license or interest shall apply to the city as for an original license on or before the date on which such sale or transfer is made. Ownership of such alcoholic beverage license shall remain unchanged until the application of such purchaser or transferee is approved by the board of aldermen and all proper fees and taxes are paid. Notwithstanding the foregoing, in the case of a corporation, a new license shall not be required as provided in this section, unless a change in stock ownership in the corporation results in ownership of more than 50 percent of the outstanding corporate stock, voting or otherwise, by persons or a combination of persons who are not owners of such stock at the time the license was issued. The term "any interest" means being an ownership of stock or control of 50 percent or more of the partnership or corporation. (b) The transfer of ownership of a business licensed under this chapter shall not affect the distance requirements previously approved by the city. (c) Upon the sale or other transfer of any interest in the business for which a license was issued under this chapter, the purchaser or transferee of such interest shall be entitled to continue to operate such business for a period of no more than 60 days, pending the issuance of a new license, but only if such purchaser or transferee has filed an application with the city as required in subsection (a) of this section. In case of the death of any natural person holding a city business license, or any interest in such license, the license may be transferred to the administrator, executor of the lawful heir or devisee of the deceased person by filing a new application with the city for the change in license ownership within 75 days of such death. The business involved may continue to operate until disposition of the application is determined as for an original license. No additional fees or business taxes shall be charged above what would be due if the business, or portion thereof, remained under the deceased person's ownership. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-14. - Completion of premises proposed to be licensed. If a building in which any person intends to operate under the provisions of this chapter is, at the time of the application for a license under this chapter, not in existence or not yet completed, a license may be issued for the location, provided, the plans for the proposed building clearly show a compliance with the other provisions of this chapter. No sales or consumption of alcoholic beverages shall be allowed in the establishment until it has been completed in accordance with the plans, and is in conformity with all of the other provisions of this chapter and this Code. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-15. - Persons with prior convictions. (a) A license under this chapter shall not be issued, renewed or transferred to any person, partnership or corporation where any individual having any interest, either as owner, partner or stockholder, directly or indirectly, beneficial or absolute, shall have been convicted of any felony within five years immediately prior to the filing of the application, or convicted of any misdemeanor relating to any alcoholic beverage business or any municipal ordinance violation relating to any alcoholic beverage business within two years immediately prior to the filing of the application. The term "any interest" means an ownership of stock or control of 50 percent or more of a partnership or corporation. (b) The term "conviction" shall include an adjudication of guilt, a plea of guilty or nolo contendere, or the forfeiture of a bond, in part or in whole, when charged with a crime, or the suspension or revocation of any alcoholic beverage license owned, in whole or in part, by persons listed in subsection (a) of this section. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-16. - Denial of license application; reapplication. (a) The board of aldermen may, in its discretion, with respect to the issuance of licenses or the transfer or renewal of licenses for the retail sale of alcoholic beverages, either by the package or to be consumed on the premises, issue or deny any license, renewal or transfer of an existing store location based upon the following standards, in addition to standards otherwise ordained in this chapter: (1) Failure to provide valid information, documents, etc., as required by this chapter; (2) False information in the application or attached documents; (3) Failure to pass review by the chief of police; (4) Failure to meet any and all requirements of chapter 10, article II of this Code; (5) Where there is evidence that the location or type of structure could create difficulty in police supervision; (6) Where there is evidence that a license for the location would be detrimental to the property values in the area; (7) Where there is evidence that the conduction of the business creates a disturbance, congregation of intoxicated persons, congregation of minors, allows minors to purchase, drink or possess alcoholic beverages on the premises, or causes the police to answer complaints or make extra surveillance of the premises; (8) Failure to comply with any other ordinance of the city; (9) Failure to comply with state requirements for a state license; (10) Failure to pay required fees and taxes; (11) Failure to post and maintain proper signs and advertisements required in this chapter; (12) Failure to meet distance or location requirements; (13) Prior convictions as provided in this article; (14) Failure to meet any other requirements of this chapter for a license of the class applied for, or any other requirement in any other provision of this Code or the city Charter; or (15) Failure to meet all city zoning requirements. (b) If an applicant for a license under this chapter is denied by the mayor and board of aldermen for the reasons set forth in subsections (a)(1)—(8) of this section, the applicant may not reapply for a license under this chapter for a period of 12 months. If an applicant for a license under this chapter is denied by the mayor and board of aldermen for the reasons set forth in subsections (a)(9)—(15) of this section, the applicant may reapply at the discretion of the mayor and board of aldermen. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-17. - State regulations. All licenses issued under this chapter shall be subject to the rules and regulations set forth in an act of the general assembly known as the Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Laws And Regulations, 1986 edition, to legalize and control alcoholic beverages and liquors, as amended, and the rules and regulations prescribed by the state department of revenue. Violation of such statutes and regulations shall be a violation of this chapter. In addition, all businesses, the applicant for a license under this chapter, the agent in charge of the licensed business and the owners of such business, shall observe and obey the regulations provided in this article, and any other applicable provisions of this chapter. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-18. - Open to inspection. Any establishment holding a license issued under this chapter shall, at all times during the hours that the establishment is open to the public, be open to inspection by any officer of the police department, any license inspector of the city or any person designated by the chief of police, or the city manager or his designee. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-19. - Open containers prohibited; exception. (a) No bottle or other containers of alcoholic beverages shall be opened or consumed by any person on the premises upon which the place of business is conducted and licensed under this chapter, whether the bottle or container so opened or consumed was bought or obtained at the place of business or elsewhere, unless the premises is licensed under this chapter for consumption on the premises, except in the case of those places of business which are licensed for a wine specialty shop. These businesses may also allow sampling of wines or craft draft beers so long as there is no charge for admittance for the wine sample or craft draft beer sample and the serving size does not exceed one and a half ounces. (b) An establishment licensed under this chapter to sell alcoholic beverages shall not allow any person to leave such licensed premises with any alcoholic beverage in an open cup, bottle, can or other open container. (c) This section shall not apply to city-sanctioned events. A city-sanctioned event is an event which is approved by a vote of the mayor and board of aldermen, or an event for which a permit is granted to any department, agency, board or commission of the city, and the city downtown development authority. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000; Ord. No. 2004-22, § 1, 6-3-2004; Ord. No. 2011-22, § 1, 9-1-2011; Ord. No. 2013-11, § 3, 4-18-2013) Sec. 6-19.1. - Open containers provisions. The purpose of this section is intended to set forth certain exceptions and provisions applicable only to licensees whose establishments: (1) Are located within the historic downtown containment district (as hereinafter defined). (2) Possess a license to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises. (3) Derive a minimum of 50 percent of its total annual gross food and beverage sales from the sale of prepared meals or food. (4) Are licensed as a wine specialty shop. Except as specifically set forth in this section, all such licensees will remain subject to all other provisions of the city's alcoholic beverages ordinance. (Ord. No. 2014-19, § 1, 7-3-2014) Sec. 6-19.2. - Definition of historic downtown containment district. For the purposes of this section only, the historic downtown containment district is defined as follows: The area generally bounded by Morningside Drive to the west, the railroad tracks to the north, the sidewalk on Lemon Street to the east, and the sidewalk on Carnes and Senator Russell Avenue to the south. The district shall also include Dallas Street from Senator Russell Avenue to the southeastern corner of City Hall, the parking lots to the east and west of the Old Jail, Frana Brown Park, and any and all public plazas and sidewalks within the boundary. Also, for purposes of this definition, any licensed establishment fronting a street within the described historic downtown containment district shall be considered to be located within the defined area. (Ord. No. 2014-19, § 1, 7-3-2014) Sec. 6-19.3. - Outside consumption of alcoholic beverages permitted. (a) Container. No container in which an alcoholic beverage is dispensed and removed from the licensed premises shall exceed sixteen (16) fluid ounces in size. No person shall hold in possession on the public streets and sidewalks, plazas, in parks and/or any other public place within the defined area any open alcoholic beverage container which exceeds 16 fluid ounces in size. Any establishment licensed to sell alcoholic beverages by the drink for consumption on the premises is authorized to dispense an alcoholic beverage in a clear plastic cup for removal from the premises. (b) Drinking from can, bottle, or glass prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to drink or attempt to drink any alcoholic beverage from an un/open can, bottle, glass, or plastic cup (other than clear) or to possess in an open can, bottle, or glass on the public streets, sidewalks, plazas, rights-of-way, and parking lots, whether public or private. (c) Purchase from licensed premises within historic downtown district. Alcoholic beverages consumed pursuant to this provision must be purchased from a licensed premises within the historic downtown district. (d) Consumption limited to certain areas in downtown district. No alcoholic beverage purchased pursuant to this provision may be consumed outside the historic downtown district or upon any private property without the consent of the property owner. (e) Regulated hours. The hours of operation for the containment area shall begin pursuant to section 6-20 and shall end at midnight. It is prohibited to be in the historic downtown district with any alcoholic beverage outside of these hours. (Ord. No. 2014-19, § 1, 7-3-2014) Sec. 6-19.4. - Signage. Any establishment that allows patrons to leave an establishment with an alcoholic beverage as regulated herein shall have an 11-inch by 17-inch sign posted at the door for public view whereas a patron exiting the establishment can read the following: "All patrons leaving this establishment with an alcoholic beverage do hereby take full responsibility to only consume an alcoholic beverage in the immediate historic downtown containment district and any individual that leaves the permitted area with an alcoholic beverage is in violation of City Code and may be subject to a citation and/or fine." (Ord. No. 2014-19, § 1, 7-3-2014) Sec. 6-19.5. - No abrogation of other laws. The provisions of this article shall not be deemed to abrogate or otherwise impact any state law or local ordinance pertaining to public drunkenness, disorderly conduct, driving with an open container or under the influence of alcohol, or similar laws. (Ord. No. 2014-19, § 1, 7-3-2014) Sec. 6-19.6. - Removal of partially consumed bottle of wine from premises. As set forth in O.C.G.A. § 3-6-4, notwithstanding any other contrary provision of law, any restaurant which is licensed to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises may permit a patron to remove one unsealed bottle of wine per patron for consumption off premises, if the patron has purchased a meal and consumed a portion of the bottle of wine which has been purchased on the premises with such meal on the restaurant's premises. A partially consumed bottle of wine that is to be removed from the premises must be securely resealed by the licensee or its employees before removal from the premises. The partially consumed bottle of wine shall be placed in a bag or other container that is secured in such a manner that it is visibly apparent if the container has been subsequently opened or tampered with, and a dated receipt for the bottle of wine and meal shall be provided by the licensee and attached to the container. If transported in a motor vehicle, the container with the resealed bottle of wine shall be placed in a locked glove compartment, a locked trunk, or the area behind the last upright seat of a motor vehicle that is not equipped with a trunk. (Ord. No. 2014-24, § 1, 10-16-2014) Sec. 6-20. - Hours and days for sale and purchase. (a) Spirituous liquor package sales. It shall be unlawful for any licensee under this chapter or person employed by a licensee to sell, offer for sale, transfer or offer to transfer to other persons packaged spirituous liquors between the hours of 11:30 p.m. on Sunday—8:00 a.m. on Monday 2:00 a.m.—8:00 a.m. on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday 12:00 a.m.—12:30 p.m. on Sunday And it shall be unlawful for any person to purchase, receive or offer to receive from a licensee or person employed by a licensee any packaged spirituous liquors during the hours listed in this section. (b) Sales by consumption on-premises licensees. It shall be unlawful for any licensee under this chapter or person employed by a licensee to sell, offer for sale, transfer or offer to transfer to any other person any spirituous liquors, malt beverages and/or wine for consumption on the premises between the hours of 2:55 a.m. on Sunday and 8:00 a.m. on the following Monday morning, and between the hours of 2:55 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. on all other days of the week; and it shall be unlawful for any person to purchase, receive or offer to receive from a licensee or person employed by a licensee any spirituous liquors, malt beverages and/or wine for consumption on the premises between the hours of 2:55 a.m. on Sunday and 8:00 a.m. on the following Monday morning, and between the hours of 2:55 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. on all other days of the week, provided, establishments licensed for consumption on the premises which derive at least 50 percent of its total annual gross food and beverage sales from the sale of prepared meals or food in all of the combined retail outlets of the individual establishment where food is served and in any licensed establishment which derives at least 50 percent of its total annual gross income from the rental of rooms for overnight lodging shall be permitted to sell spirituous liquors and/or malt beverages on Sundays between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and midnight upon approval and issuance of a permit authorizing such sales. License applications shall be submitted to the city manager who shall issue such licenses upon payment of a fee as established from time to time by the mayor and board of aldermen to establishments meeting the applicable requirements of this chapter and/or state law. In the case of restaurants, the alcoholic beverage Sunday sales license application and the required fees may be submitted at the same time as all other license applications. The city shall have 90 days to determine if the application qualifies for Sunday sales of alcoholic beverages. During such 90-day period, the applicant shall be granted a temporary permit which shall automatically expire 90 days after issuance. If the applicant qualifies for Sunday sales of alcoholic beverages, then the applicant shall be issued an annual Sunday sales permit. If the applicant qualifies for Sunday sales of alcoholic beverages, no further fees shall be necessary. If the applicant does not qualify for Sunday sales of alcoholic beverages, the city will retain all fees paid under this subsection, including the $200.00 processing fee. (1) In the event New Year's Eve (December 31st) falls on a Sunday, notwithstanding any other provisions contained within this Code to the contrary, persons, firms, or corporations owning or operating a place of business licensed under Chapter 6, Article 1, section 6-20 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Acworth, Georgia (for Sunday sales) may sell, offer for sale, and/or permit the consumption of spirituous liquors, malt beverages, and/or wine upon the business premises between the hours of 12:01 a.m. and 2:55 a.m. on Monday, in addition to the hours otherwise authorized for such activity under Chapter 6 of said Code. (c) Malt beverages and wine package sales. It shall be unlawful for any licensee under this chapter or person employed by a licensee to sell, offer for sale, transfer or offer to transfer to other persons packaged malt beverages or wine between the hours of 11:30 p.m. on Sunday—8:00 a.m. on Monday 2:00 a.m.—8:00 a.m. on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday 12:00 a.m.—12:30 p.m. on Sunday And it shall be unlawful for any person to purchase, receive or offer to receive from a licensee or person employed by a licensee any malt beverages or wine during the hours listed in this section. (d) Election day sales. Pursuant to the delegation of authority granted to the mayor and board of aldermen by Act No. 750 (House Bill No. 247) effective July 1, 1985, amending O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20(b)(2)(B), the sale, by wholesale and retail, of alcoholic beverages, distilled spirits and/or wine and malt beverages shall be lawful during the polling hours of any election; provided, however, nothing in this subsection shall authorize the sale of alcoholic beverages within 250 feet of a polling place during such time as the polls are open. (e) Change of time affecting closing hours. On the days when the time changes, a licensee under this chapter shall determine the closing hour of his licensed establishment at the end of the business day by the same time on which he opened that regular business day. The closing hour for the sale and purchase of spirituous liquors, malt beverages or wine under this subsection shall be determined as follows: (1) On the day when the time changes from Eastern Standard Time to Daylight Savings Time, the closing hour shall be determined by Eastern Standard Time. (2) On the day when the time changes from Daylight Savings Time to Eastern Standard Time, the closing hour shall be determined by Daylight Savings Time. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000; Ord. No. 2006-52, § 1, 12-21-2006; Ord. No. 2011-27, § 1, 11-17-2011; Ord. No. 2012-07, § 1, 4-5-2012) Editor's note— Res. No. RS2018-13, adopted June 21, 2018, called for a municipal special election to be held on Nov. 6, 2018, for a referendum to allow the city to authorize and permit the regulation of Sunday sales of distilled spirits, or alcoholic beverages by the drink from 11:00 a.m.to 12:30 p.m. Sec. 6-21. - Where drinking prohibited; exception. It shall be unlawful for any person to drink any whiskey, wine, beer or other alcoholic beverage while upon the streets, sidewalks, parks or public places of the city, or upon or within any vehicle upon the premises or in any adjacent parking area of any business establishment holding a license under this chapter, except as may be permitted under subsection 6-19(c). (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-22. - Drive-in and curb service. (a) Curb service by retail or consumption on the premises licensed under this chapter, or delivery of any alcoholic beverages off the licensed premises, other than by wholesalers licensed under this chapter, or by the state, shall be prohibited. (b) Drive-in service windows at premises licensed under this chapter are prohibited, except as otherwise provided in this section. (c) Businesses licensed by the city for the retail sale of only malt beverages and/or wine may only provide drive-in service windows as follows: (1) The drive-in window shall be clear and unobstructed for a minimum of 24 inches wide and 36 inches in height. (2) The location of the drive-in window shall be lighted in a manner that will enable the attendant of the window to clearly view the entire interior of any vehicle being served at the window. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-23. - Minors. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person within the city under 21 years of age to buy, or allow to be bought for him, any alcoholic beverage from any place where such beverages are kept. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person in charge of or employed in any place of business where alcoholic beverages are kept to permit any person under 21 years of age to buy, or allow to be bought for any person under 21 years of age, any alcoholic beverages in or from such place of business, or to frequent or loiter about the premises unless such minor is accompanied by a parent or guardian. (c) It shall be unlawful for any person to furnish or serve to any person under 21 years of age any alcoholic beverage. A valid driver's license, state identification card or military identification card may be reasonably accepted by the person serving such alcoholic beverage as sufficient evidence of a person's age. (d) It shall be unlawful for any person to commit an act which is made unlawful by this section and such act shall be unlawful and subject to punishment in the municipal court. (e) It shall be unlawful for any person under 21 years of age to falsely represent his age in any manner for the purpose of illegally obtaining alcoholic beverages. (f) It shall be unlawful for any person to allow or require a person in his employment who is under 18 years of age to dispense, serve, sell or take orders for any alcoholic beverage; provided, however, that the provisions of this subsection shall not prohibit persons under 18 years of age who are employed in supermarkets, convenience stores or drugstores from selling or handling alcoholic beverages which are sold for consumption off the premises. (g) It shall be unlawful for any person who is under 21 years of age to have in his possession, or under his control, at any place within the city, any alcoholic beverage, unless otherwise provided by law. (h) Violation of any provision of this section shall constitute an offense, and shall be punishable in the municipal court, provided, violation of this section by persons who have not yet reached the age of 17 years shall be punished as provided by O.C.G.A. §§ 3-3-2 et seq. and 15-11-1 et seq. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) State Law reference— Municipal court jurisdiction is granted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 36-32-10. Sec. 6-24. - Duration and renewal of license. (a) Alcoholic beverage license renewals within the city shall be due on or before December 31 of the year in which the license expires; and no licensee shall have any vested right to the renewal of any city license. Renewals of alcoholic beverage licenses may be made after December 31, and shall be subject to a ten-percent penalty and one percent interest, per month, for delinquency. (b) No licenses under this chapter may be renewed if the licensee could be denied a new license under this chapter, except as provided in section 6-27. (c) The city manager shall have the right to place the matter before the mayor and board of aldermen if there is a substantial change since the last renewal of a license under this chapter. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-25. - Distance and area requirements. (a) Unless the following uses of property are nonconforming under the city's zoning regulations, no person shall be licensed by the city under this chapter where the proposed place of business is located within a distance of 200 feet of any church, school or college; provided, however, that if a church, school or college is located in a commercially zoned district and is granted a special land use permit to operate, then there shall be no distance requirement. (b) For any spirituous liquor licenses for retail consumption on the premises, or otherwise, the distance requirement from schools and colleges shall be 300 feet. (c) No alcoholic beverage pouring license shall be issued to any person when the front door of the proposed place of business is located within 50 feet of the front corner of any parcel of land which is zoned as single-family residential use. The distance shall be measured from the nearest corner of the front yard of the nearest residence zoned as a single-family residential use to the front door of the proposed licensee's premises along the nearest practical street route. (d) Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this section, no church which becomes located within the central business district after December 20, 1994, shall be entitled to object to the location of a licensee under this chapter, and no license shall be denied because such business is within the prohibited footage as set forth in subsection (a) of this section when such footage is applied to a church which was located within the central business district after December 20, 1994. (e) The mayor and board of aldermen may, in its discretion, issue or deny any license under this chapter where there is evidence that the type and number of schools, churches, libraries or public recreation areas in the vicinity of the place of business of the licensee causes minors to frequent the immediate area, even though there is a compliance with the minimum distances as provided in this section. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000; Ord. No. 2005-22, 5-5-2005) Sec. 6-26. - Manager's permit. (a) Every person licensed under this chapter for the retail sale of spirituous liquor, malt beverages or wine for consumption on the premises shall employ one or more persons as manager for the licensed establishment. At least one manager shall be at the licensee's premises during all times that alcoholic beverages are being consumed on such licensed establishment, and such manager shall be in charge of the premises and responsible for the actions of the employees and customers of the licensed establishment. In lieu of being present on the premises, the manager shall be authorized to certify that the manager shall have the ability to be, and will be, present on the premises within 45 minutes of being notified of the need for his presence on the premises. Each such manager shall obtain a manager's permit as provided in this section, and such permit shall be valid for a period of 12 months from the date of issuance of such permit. (b) Every person wishing to obtain a manager's permit under this section shall make application on forms provided by the city clerk's office within three days of the date of employment. Upon receiving the completed application, the police department shall arrange to have a complete and exhaustive search made relative to any police record of the person fingerprinted and photographed and such records shall be placed on file in the city clerk's office. The city clerk shall be authorized to issue a manager's permit as provided in subsection (e) of this section after verifying the facts in the application and criminal record, if applicable. (1) In the event there is a criminal record discovered that would exclude the issuance of a manager's permit, the city clerk shall issue a letter to the applicant and the employer, stating that the person is ineligible for a permit and/or employment. (2) Any employee excluded from receiving or holding a manager's permit under the terms of this section shall have the right to appeal such exclusion to the governing body, which may in its discretion approve the issuance of a manager's permit. (3) The failure of an employee to obtain a manager's permit will not prohibit the employee from applying for and receiving one if all other conditions of this section are otherwise met. (c) Licensees and managers under this section shall keep a copy of the manager's permit on file, at all times, in the licensed establishment, and shall make such permits available for inspection during operating hours. (d) Any person who has been convicted of a violation of any law or ordinance governing the sale of alcoholic beverages or sale or possession of illegal drugs in the past 12 months shall be ineligible to receive a manager's permit under this section. (e) If any manager of a licensee under this chapter shall cease to be an employee of the licensee, or shall cease to be a resident of the United States, or in any manner ceases to meet the requirements of this section, the licensee shall notify the city manager or his/her designee, and shall name a new manager within three days thereafter. Such new manager shall meet all of the requirements of this section. (f) The fee for a manager's permit, including a change of the licensee's manager, shall be $30.00, provided, further, that if the licensee fails to notify the city of an employed manager and/or name a new manager within the three-day period set forth in this subsection, then the city shall charge a fee of $50.00 for a newly employed manager and/or change of the licensee's manager, and/or revoke the licensee's license. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000; Ord. No. 2005-22, 5-5-2005; Ord. No. 2008-26, § 1, 11-6-08) Sec. 6-27. - Compliance. (a) To prevent an unconstitutional taking of property, all licensees for the sale of alcoholic beverages within the city in compliance with city ordinance requirements involving residency, distance, location, parking and type of building structure in effect at the time of first receiving such licenses, and continuing to be in compliance with such requirements, shall be exempt from the requirements of this chapter involving residency, distance, location, parking and type of building structure. Renewals of such licenses shall also be deemed to be in compliance to the extent provided in this subsection. (b) Transfers of business ownership at the same location shall be deemed in compliance with regard to the city ordinance requirements involving distance, location, parking and type of building structure, provided, that such business complied with such requirements at the time a license was first issued for such business and, provided further, that such business has continuously been in compliance with such requirements. (c) Business transfers to new locations and new licenses must comply with all requirements of this chapter. (d) If a business which has been previously issued a current alcoholic beverage license ceases to operate or closes its business for any reason, and a new business located on the same premises applies for an alcoholic beverage license at that location within 365 days next following the day after which the prior business ceases operations, the city shall be authorized to approve or reject such license application, as provided under this chapter, even though a church has been established within the distance restrictions set forth in section 6-25 with respect to the prior business if the church was established in its location after the issuance of an alcoholic beverage license to the prior business. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-28. - Happy hour promotions. (a) All alcoholic beverage sales for consumption on the premises licensees within the city are prohibited from selling or giving away alcoholic beverages under the following circumstances: (1) Serving multiple drinks for a single price, or offering all you can drink for a set price, during a set time. (2) Making a single price the basis for a required purchase of two or more servings. (3) Sponsoring, conducting or allowing contests or other promotions which have as their primary purpose the increase of the consumption of alcoholic beverages. (4) Offering or delivering any free alcoholic beverages to the general public. (b) This section shall not apply to private functions not open to the public. The term "private functions not open to the public" means any function wherein the licensee has agreed to the use of the licensee's establishment by a person for a set period of time for valuable consideration. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-29. - Temporary permit for nonprofit or charitable organizations or special events. Temporary permits may be issued by the mayor and board of aldermen to nonprofit or charitable organizations or special events approved by the mayor and board of aldermen in accordance with the requirements specified in this section, as follows: (1) The application for a temporary permit shall comply, in all respects, with the requirements contained in this chapter, and such application shall be processed in accordance with this chapter and in the normal course of processing applications in the city. (2) The applicant for a temporary permit must be a bona fide nonprofit or charitable organization, and must supply with the original application proof of its exempt status as granted by the Internal Revenue Service, or must be a group sanctioned by the mayor and board of aldermen to hold a special event. (3) The temporary permit shall be in effect for the length of the event for which such permit is requested, or three days, whichever is shorter. After the expiration of such period of time, the permit shall expire. A temporary permit may be applied for and granted no more than two times during any 12-month period. (4) The fee for a temporary permit shall be $100.00 per alcoholic beverage requested to be sold. (5) The temporary permit granted under this section shall be deemed to be a privilege permit. The permit application shall be processed in accordance with this chapter, and shall be presented to the mayor and board of aldermen, which may take action, as it deems appropriate. The board of aldermen may also approve or disapprove the days and hours of operation for the temporary permit. (6) The applicant for a temporary permit shall also comply with all applicable state laws related to the application for a temporary permit, and shall obtain all necessary state permits. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-30. - Growlers. The sale of growlers in compliance with this ordinance is authorized for establishments licensed in subsection(s) 6-4(4) and 6-4(5) of this chapter authorized to sell alcoholic beverages, excluding spirituous liquors by the package. The filling of growlers by means of a tapped keg shall not constitute the breaking of a package as contemplated by O.C.G.A. § 3-3-26 or other provisions of this [chapter]. The term "growler" means a properly sanitized reusable bottle made of glass or other material customary to the industry provided that the bottle is capable of being sealed with a screw cap and then sealed with a plastic collar over the screw for the purpose of complying with open container laws, and further provided that the bottle does not exceed 64 ounces and is filled by a licensee or employee of the licensed establishment with craft beer from a keg for off-premises consumption. Growlers may only be filled from kegs procured by the licensee from a duly licensed wholesaler. Only properly sanitized and sealed growlers may be filled and made available for retail sale. Each growler must be securely sealed and removed from the premises in its original sealed condition. The licensee must comply with all state, federal and local packaging and labeling laws regarding alcoholic beverages. Consumption on the premises is strictly prohibited. However, samples of craft beers from tap may be made available, but shall not exceed one and a half ounces (1.5 oz.) nor shall any one individual be offered more than three samples within a calendar day. The annual fee for sale of growlers shall be set, and may be revised, by ordinance of the mayor and board. (Ord. No. 2013-11, § 4, 4-18-2013) Sec. 6-31. - Violation; penalties. (a) It is declared that a violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a violation of this Code, and upon conviction of such violation in the municipal court, the punishment shall be as set forth in section 1-11. (b) Upon conviction in the municipal court of a violation of any provision of this chapter or any state or federal law, the mayor and board of aldermen shall be authorized to revoke, probate or suspend, as a civil matter, the alcoholic beverage license previously granted under this chapter. The licensee shall be given written notification of such action, and such notice shall contain a specification of the violation and shall be served upon the licensee at least five days prior to the notice of the hearing. The licensee shall be given notice of the time and place of the hearing. The license shall not be revoked, probated or suspended until a final decision is rendered by the mayor and board of aldermen at the hearing. Any licensee aggrieved by the action of the mayor and board of aldermen may appeal to the county superior court within 30 days from the date of the decision to revoke, probate or suspend the license. (c) Whenever the state shall revoke any permit or license to manufacture or sell at wholesale or retail any alcoholic beverages, the city license to manufacture or deal in such products shall be automatically revoked without any action by the mayor or board of aldermen or any municipal officer. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000; Ord. No. 2013-11, § 5, 4-18-2013; Ord. No. 2013-20, § 2, 5-16-2013) Editor's note— Ord. No. 2013-11, § 5, adopted 4-18-2013 and Ord. No. 2013-20, § 2, adopted 5-16-2013 renumbered the former section 6-30 as section 6-31. Sec. 6-32. - Revocation. (a) The city manager or his/her designee shall be authorized to suspend or revoke an alcoholic license in accordance with the procedures set forth below. In the event the city manager or his/her designee seeks to suspend or revoke an occupation tax certificate, the city manager or his/her designee shall give written notification to the applicant of such action and such notice shall contain a specification of the violation or violations and shall be served upon the licensee at least five days prior to the hearing. The applicant shall be given written notice of the time and place of the hearing. (b) The city manager or his/her designee shall be authorized to suspend or revoke an alcoholic license in the event of any one or more of the following: (1) An applicant gave false or misleading information in the original or renewal application process; (2) An applicant has knowingly allowed possession, use, or sale of controlled substances on the premises and/or knowingly allowed possession, use or sale of controlled substances to a minor on the premises; (3) An applicant has knowingly allowed the violation of an ordinance of the city or a violation of any criminal law of the state (a misdemeanor or a felony) to occur on the premises; and that such violation is materially related to the operation of said business; (4) An applicant (or licensee) has been convicted of any drug-related, alcohol-related or sex-related crime by the state or the city regarding an offense which was committed on the premises or which would otherwise violate the provisions of this chapter; (5) An applicant fails to pay any fee, occupation tax, fine or other amount of money due to the city under this chapter or any other taxing ordinance of the city; and (6) An applicant or the owner alters or allows to be altered; the alcohol license or the applicant, or the owner changes the information, defaces, destroys, misuses, abuses, or improperly alters or misrepresents the alcohol license certificate. (c) In the event the city manager or his/her designee shall suspend or revoke any alcohol license, the suspension or revocation shall be for a period of not less than one day, nor more than 365 days, within the discretion of the city manager. Any suspension or revocation shall be sent by the city by certified mail, return receipt requested. No applicant may apply for an alcohol license during any period of suspension or revocation. In any hearing conducted, the city manager shall consider, among other things, the severity of the allegations, the evidence submitted and the testimony presented, in making any decision on suspension or revocation and the duration of either. (d) An applicant or any interested person may appeal an administrative action or decision of the city manager. An appeal must be made to the board of aldermen. All appeals shall be submitted in writing, shall state reasons for the appeal, and shall be filed with the city clerk within ten days of the decision. The board shall give at least 15-days' notice before hearing the appeal. Such notice shall be given to the general public and parties of interest. The board may affirm, reverse, or modify the decision of the city manager. (Ord. No. 2008-17, 6-19-2008; Ord. No. 2013-11, § 5, 4-18-2013; Ord. No. 2013-20, § 3, 5-16-2013; Ord. No. 2017-22, 12-21-2017) Editor's note— Ord. No. 2013-11, § 5, adopted 4-18-2013 and Ord. No. 2013-20, § 3, adopted 5-16-2013 renumbered the former section 6-31 as section 6-32. Sec. 6-33. - Reporting of disciplinary actions. (a) Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2.1, the City of Acworth shall be required to provide notification to the Georgia Department of Revenue within 45 days of any officer, department, agency, or instrumentality of the municipality taking disciplinary action against any person issued a license to operate any premises at which 75 percent or more total gross annual revenue is derived from the sales of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises. (b) The notification required under paragraph (a) of this Code section shall be in the format for the reporting of disciplinary actions set by the Georgia Department of Revenue. (c) For purposes of this Code section "disciplinary action" shall have the same meaning as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2.1(a)(1), which includes any citation or arrest arising out of the violation of any law, rule, regulation, resolution, or ordinance of a governmental entity relating to the manufacture, distribution, sale, or possession of alcoholic beverages against a licensee, any employee of a licensee, or any person holding a financial interest in the license of a licensee on the premises or place of business of any licensee. (Ord. No. 2016-33, § 1, 8-18-2016) Secs. 6-34—6-50. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - RETAIL SPIRITUOUS LIQUORS
Sec. 6-51. - Conflict of provisions. In addition to the general business license requirements of this Code and article I of this chapter, this article shall apply to the licensing and operation of retail spirituous liquor establishments in the city, and if any section of this article conflicts with other provisions in this chapter or the general business license requirements of this Code, then this article shall control. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-52. - Limitation on number of licenses within a family or corporation. (a) No application for a license to sell spirituous liquors at retail within the city shall be granted where the person applying for the license, or any person who would have an interest in such license, or members of such person's family, or any corporation in which the person owns an interest already holds any interest in two or more licenses to sell spirituous liquor by the package at retail within the state. The term "family," as used in this section, means any spouse, brother, sister, child or parent of the applicant, or any other person who would have an interest in the retail spirituous liquors license. (b) As used in this section, an interest in a license shall be deemed to exist if the person involved is the outright owner of the license; a co-owner of the license; a partner in a partnership which owns all or any part of a license; a stockholder in any corporation organized for pecuniary gain which owns all, or any part of, a license. Notwithstanding any of the other provisions of this section, no one person shall be deemed to have more than one interest in any one license. (c) All applications for a retail spirituous liquors license, both original and renewal, must be accompanied by a full and complete statement, under oath, of information relative to any and all interest, as defined in subsection (b) of this section, in retail liquor stores. This shall include the names and addresses of all persons interested in the ownership of the business of selling package liquor at retail, together with any interest each person, or any member of his family, has in any other retail liquor store, and any other similar information called for by the police department or city manager. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-53. - Sale of other merchandise. A licensee of a retail spirituous liquor establishment under this article shall not operate the business in connection with any other mercantile establishment, provided, this shall not prohibit a retail spirituous liquor licensee from operating in the same building complex with other businesses. No retail spirituous liquor licensee shall sell, offer for sale, display or keep in stock at his place of business where packaged spirituous liquors are offered for sale any other commodity except the following, all of which may he sold by the retailer at his option: (1) Beverages containing no alcohol and commonly used to dilute distilled spirits; (2) Wines and malt beverages, when properly licensed; (3) Glasses, stirring sticks and similar paraphernalia commonly used in the consumption of alcoholic beverages; (4) Tobacco products; and (5) Packaged ice. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Secs. 6-54—6-85. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - EXCISE TAX
Sec. 6-86. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: City manager means the city manager of the City of Acworth or his agent. Person means associations, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate, or any combination thereof, as well as individuals. Retailer means a person who sells alcoholic beverages to a consumer or any other person for any purpose other than for resale in the form of tangible personal property, and holds a city license for retail sales or for consumption on the premises. Wholesaler means a person who sells alcoholic beverages to jobbers or to another person other than the consumer, or anything in the form of tangible personal property. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 6-87. - Levy and computation. (a) In addition to all other taxes or license fees imposed upon retailers selling malt beverages, wine or spirituous liquors at retail or for consumption on the premises in the city, there is levied and imposed upon each such retailer the following excise taxes: (1) Upon the sale of any malt beverages there shall be imposed an excise tax of $0.05 per 12-ounce container, and $6.00 for each container of tap or draft beer of 15½ gallons and in similar proportions for bottles, cans and containers of various sizes, as follows: Size of Container Tax Per Container 7 ounces $ 0.0292 8 ounces 0.0333 12 ounces 0.0500 14 ounces 0.0583 16 ounces 0.0667 32 ounces 0.1333 ½ barrel (15½ gallons) 6.00 1 barrel (31 gallons) 12.00
(2) Upon the sale of wine there shall be imposed an excise tax of $0.22 per liter. (3) Upon the sale of any spirituous liquors there shall be imposed an excise tax of $0.22 per liter. (b) The taxes set forth in subsection (a) of this section shall be collected by the wholesaler at the time of sale to the retailer. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-88. - Retailers dealing with wholesalers; registration of wholesalers. (a) No retailer of alcoholic beverages in the city shall purchase, or otherwise receive, alcoholic beverages for any wholesaler not registered under this section. Any retailer failing to comply with such requirement shall be subject to revocation of any and all city business licenses held by him, and any other penalty which may be imposed for violation of this Code. (b) Unless a wholesaler of alcoholic beverages is licensed by the city, he shall not take orders from or make deliveries to any retailer in alcoholic beverages within the city unless and until the wholesaler registers with the city manager on a form provided by the city, and otherwise satisfies the requirements of this article placed on such wholesalers. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-89. - Wholesaler's reports; tax collection; payment; records. (a) Each wholesaler registered under this article or licensed by the city shall file a report with the city clerk by the tenth day of each month, itemizing for the preceding calendar month the exact quantities of all alcoholic beverages, by size and type of container, sold within the city. The report shall include the name and address of each retailer with which the wholesaler did business in the city, and any other information as may be required by the city manager. (b) Each wholesaler making a report under this section shall collect from each retailer with whom the wholesaler did business the amount of tax due the city under this article, and shall hold such tax in trust for the city. (c) Each wholesaler's monthly report shall be accompanied by remittance to the city of all taxes due the city under this article for the preceding month from each retailer. (d) Each wholesaler making a report under this section shall keep true and correct records, including invoices, of all sales, shipments or deliveries of beverages to retailers in the city. Such records shall be preserved for at least one year, and shall be made available, on request, for inspection by any authorized representative of the city. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-90. - Wholesaler's deposit. Each new wholesaler licensed by the city or registered with the city, whether located outside or within the city limits, shall be required to place three months of the tax required by this article on deposit with the city. Such deposit shall be an amount equal to the amount of tax paid by the wholesaler during the first month of operation in the city, and shall be deposited at the same time as the first payment of taxes. The deposit shall be retained by the city, to be applied to make up for any default on the part of the wholesaler, and shall be refunded to the wholesaler upon the wholesaler ceasing to do business in the city, provided, the wholesaler is current in its remission of taxes. The deposit shall be adjusted each year to be an average of 1/12 of the previous year's tax collections. A surety bond payable to the city may be posted in lieu of the deposit if such bond is in an amount equal to twice the deposit required. The deposit or bond required by this section shall be waived by the city manager upon a showing by the wholesaler that it has timely paid the tax levied by section 6-87 for a period of five consecutive years; provided, however, that if such deposit or bond is so waived, the city manager shall have the right to reinstitute the requirement of making such deposit or posting such bond if the wholesaler thereafter fails to make timely payment of the tax levied by section 6-87 with respect to any month. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-91. - Unlawful retail sales. It shall be unlawful for any retailer within the city to sell any alcoholic beverages on which the taxes under this article have not been paid by the retailer. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-92. - Failure to make timely report or remittance; false or fraudulent reports; penalty; revocation of license. (a) The failure to make a timely report or remittance shall render a wholesaler under this article liable for a penalty equal to ten percent of the total amount due and a further penalty of ten percent of the amount of the remittance for each successive month, or any portion thereof, during which the report and remittance are not filed. The filing of a false or fraudulent report shall render the wholesaler making the false or fraudulent report liable for a penalty equal to ten percent of the amount of the remittance which would be required under an accurate and truthful report. (b) Any failure to make a timely report or remittance, or the filing of a false or fraudulent report, shall also constitute grounds for the revocation of the business license or registration issued by the city to the wholesaler. (c) The penalties and revocation set forth in subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall be in addition to any other penalty which may be imposed for a violation of this Code. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Sec. 6-93. - Sale of distilled spirits by the drink. (a) Pursuant to the authority contained in O.C.G.A. § 3-4-130, there is imposed and levied a tax on the sale of distilled spirits by the drink, which tax shall be equal to three percent of the charge to the public for such drink. (b) The tax imposed by this section shall be paid monthly, with payment due on the 20th day of the month following the month for which such tax is to be paid. (c) Any taxes imposed by this section which are not timely paid shall incur a penalty of ten percent of the amount of such taxes, and bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, or any fraction thereof. (d) Operators collecting the tax for the sale of distilled spirits by the drink shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and payment of the amount due, if such amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of deduction shall be three percent of the gross tax or $25.00, whichever is less. (Ord. No. 2000-3, 3-2-2000) Secs. 6-94—6-99. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES CATERERS
Sec. 6-100. - Scope of article. In addition to the general business license requirements of this Code and Article I of this chapter, the following sections shall apply to the licensing and operation of all establishments selling alcoholic beverages for consumption off-premises in connection with an authorized catered event or function and should any section of this article conflict with other provisions in this chapter or the general business license requirements of this Code, then this article shall control. (Ord. No. 2009-14, § 2, 10-15-2009; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 2, 11-5-2009) Sec. 6-101. - Definitions. In addition to the definitions provided in Section 6-1 and other sections of this Code, the following words shall have the indicated meaning for purposes of this article: Food caterer shall mean any person who prepares food for consumption off the premises. Licensed alcoholic beverage caterer shall mean any business licensed for consumption on premises of malt beverages, wine, or distilled spirits pursuant to Chapter 6, of the City of Acworth, Georgia, Code of Ordinances Person shall extend and be applied to associations, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate, or any combination thereof, as well as to individuals. (Ord. No. 2009-14, § 2, 10-15-2009; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 2, 11-5-2009) Sec. 6-102. - Alcoholic beverage license required. (a) Any alcoholic beverage caterer who possesses a valid alcohol pouring for consumption on premises of malt beverages, wine, or distilled spirits license from the City of Acworth or another city or county in Georgia and possesses a valid license from the state of Georgia to sell malt beverages, wine, or distilled spirits by the drink within the city may be issued by the city an event permit authorizing such sales off-premises at a fixed location in the City and in connection with an authorized catered event or function. (b) A licensed alcoholic beverage caterer may only sell that which is authorized by his alcoholic beverage license. For example, if the alcoholic beverage caterer possesses a valid license to sell malt beverages, he may only sell malt beverages at the authorized catered event or function. (c) An alcoholic beverage caterer shall submit an application for an off-premises event permit to the city manager. The license may be applied for at the same time as the alcoholic beverages license(s). (d) It is unlawful for any person to engage in, carry on or conduct the sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages off-premises and in connection with a catered event or function without first having obtained a permit as provided herein. (Ord. No. 2009-14, § 2, 10-15-2009; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 2, 11-5-2009) Sec. 6-103. - Food caterer. Any food caterer, as defined herein, operating within the city shall apply for an alcoholic beverage caterer's license in order to distribute or sell any distilled spirits, malt beverages or wine off the premises of the food caterer's business. This does not affect any requirements that the food caterer have a license to sell alcoholic beverages on the premises of the food caterer's business. (Ord. No. 2009-14, § 2, 10-15-2009; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 2, 11-5-2009) Sec. 6-104. - Event permit and application—Fee. (a) Exclusive of the license required herein, each alcoholic beverage caterer wishing to sell or distribute distilled spirits, malt beverages, or wine at an authorized catered event or function within the city must apply for an event permit. The application for the event permit shall include the name of the caterer; the date, address, time and name of the event; and the quantity of alcoholic beverages to be transported from the licensee's primary location to the location of the authorized catered event or function. (b) The event permit fee shall be $50.00 per event for those caterers located outside the City of Acworth; the event permit fee shall be $10.00 for those caterers located inside the city.
