The IRCA stipulates that the employment verification process be completed in person and that verification be completed within three working days of the beginning of employment and backdating of forms is prohibited. (1) The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Social Security Administration (SSA) have established an electronic system called E-Verify to assist employers further in verifying the employment eligibility of all newly-hired employees. (2) The failure to complete the I-9 employment verification process within the time limits prescribed is a violation and may subject the city to civil and/or criminal liability. (Ord. No. 2013-06, § 1, 3-21-2013) Sec. 62-61. - Procedures. (a) Upon acceptance of an offer of employment or within three working days of the first day of employment, human resources must complete and/or receive a completed I-9 form to have employment eligibility verified. (b) The documents used by the employee to substantiate employment eligibility must be inspected for authenticity, and only an authorized trained representative must sign the I-9 form. (c) All departments are prohibited from employing individuals who have not successfully completed the I-9 employment verification process within three working days of date of hire from employing any undocumented worker. This includes independent contractors, staffing agencies, and recruitment firms that use undocumented workers. (d) If the employee is unable to present acceptable document(s) or resolve a "no match" letter if received from the Social Security Administration within the third business day after employment, the employee will be given an additional seven business days to resolve any issues. During this time the employees' employment will not be affected and the employee will be afforded the opportunity to resolve any discrepancy in order for the city to verify employment eligibility. However, continued failure of the employee to submit the required I-9 documentation or to resolve any discrepancy may result in immediate termination until the issue is resolved. (e) The human resources department will contact any active employees whose I-9 documentation has expired. The human resources department will be responsible for following-up on non-compliance with personnel liaisons and directly with employees as needed. (f) Upon request, human resources may delegate responsibility for verification of employment eligibility; such departments shall typically have a high level of seasonal hiring activity. (g) Individuals with such authority must receive training on form I-9 reporting requirements and identification of falsified identification. The human resources department will provide such training and maintain a list of employees authorized to approve I-9 forms. (h) I-9 forms and copies of the acceptable documents that were reviewed by the departments must be sent to the human resources department. The human resources department will review the I-9 forms for completeness and process in the E-Verify system. (i) All records regarding verification of employment eligibility will be maintained by the human resources department. (j) In the first quarter of each year an audit will be conducted of previous calendar year documents related to the verification of employment eligibility. In compliance with Image Best Employment Practices, trained employees not otherwise involved in the I-9 process will conduct the audit process approved by the internal audit manager and the results reported to the city manager. (Ord. No. 2013-06, § 1, 3-21-2013) Secs. 62-62—62-90. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - SALARY PLAN
Sec. 62-91. - Coverage. The schedule of salary ranges and the assignment of classes to salary ranges which are attached to the ordinance from which this section is derived shall be the salary plan of the city. The salary plan shall include all permanent classes of positions included in the classification plan. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-92. - Administration and maintenance. The city manager shall be responsible for the administration and maintenance of the salary plan. Each year, prior to the preparation of the annual budget, the city manager shall secure information concerning the general level of salaries paid and fringe benefits provided in private industry in the area; the salaries paid and fringe benefits provided to comparable municipal, county and state employees; and any change in the cost of living in the area during the fiscal year. The city manager shall conduct continuing studies of the internal relationships between classes in order to reduce or eliminate inequities between classes of positions. Based on the studies and the general financial condition of the city governmental unit, the city manager shall recommend to the board of aldermen such increases, reductions or amendments of the salary plan as the city manager deems necessary to maintain the fairness and adequacy of the plan. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-93. - Transition to a new plan. The following principles shall govern the transition to a new salary plan: (1) No employee shall receive a salary reduction as a result of the transition to the new salary plan. (2) All employees being paid at a rate lower than the minimum rate established for their respective class shall have their salaries raised to the new minimum for their class. (3) All employees being paid at a rate that falls within the employee's new salary range shall not have their salary adjusted until merit increases are approved. (4) All employees being paid at a rate above the maximum rate established for their respective class shall remain at their present salary as long as the maximum rate is below the employee's present salary. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-94. - Payment at a listed rate. All city employees covered by the salary plan shall be paid at a rate within the salary ranges established for their respective job classifications, except employees in a trainee status or employees whose present salaries are above the established maximum rate following transition to a new pay plan. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-95. - Entrance. (a) Each new city employee shall be appointed at the minimum salary that has been established for the classification in which they are employed, except: (1) If the new employee does not meet the minimum requirements of the position and a qualified applicant for the position is not available, the city manager may designate the employee as a trainee and shall be appointed at a salary below the minimum. (2) When the city manager determines that there has been a demonstrated inability to recruit at the minimum salary, or that an applicant possesses exceptional qualifications, the city manager may authorize the employment of the applicant at a higher rate than the minimum in the salary range. (b) An employee shall not be eligible for a merit pay increase until he has been on the job for at least six months. Any new employee shall only be eligible for a merit pay increase at his six-month anniversary if the city authorized and gave out merit pay increases to other employees while such employee was in his first six months of employment. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-96. - Trainee. A new city employee who does not meet all of the established qualifications for a position may be appointed with the approval of the city manager at a training salary of no more than ten percent below the minimum salary established for the position. The employee shall continue to receive a reduced salary during the probational period until the appointing department head, with the approval of the city manager, shall determine that the trainee is qualified to assume the responsibilities of the position, or until the end of the probationary period, when the employee is either discharged or moved to a listed rate in the salary range established for the position. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-97. - Salary merit increases. Salary merit increases above the minimum established for each class of positions may be granted each year after annual performance evaluations. The city manager shall include funds in the budget proposal each year for providing earned salary increases. Insofar as practicable, each department shall receive a share of the funds for salary increases in proportion to the department's share of the total salaries paid to employees. Regardless of the merit increase approved by the board of aldermen for employees as a whole, no individual employee shall receive a merit increase that puts the employee above the maximum pay in his designated salary range. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-98. - Employee review system. There shall be an employee evaluation procedure on an annual basis. Each review form shall become a permanent record of the city when filled out and turned in by an employee's supervisor. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-99. - Reclassified employee. (a) A city employee whose position is reclassified to a class having a higher pay range shall receive an increase in pay equal to the minimum step of the new salary range, or an increase based on the employee's present pay in the lower range, plus up to five percent, at the department head's and city manager's discretion, whichever is higher. (b) An employee whose position is reclassified to a class having a lower pay range shall not receive a reduction in salary as a result of the reclassification. However, the employee shall not be eligible for a salary merit increase until he falls within the new pay range of his new classification. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-100. - Promoted employee. A city employee who is promoted to a position in a class having a higher pay range shall get the higher of either the starting pay of the new range or the employee's present pay in the lower range, plus up to seven percent, at the department head's and city manager's discretion. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-101. - Transferred employee. Except upon the written consent of the affected employee, the salary of an employee who is reassigned to a position in the same or a different department with the same salary range shall not be decreased by the reassignment. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-102. - Demoted employee. The salary of an employee who is demoted to a position in a class with a lower salary range shall be adjusted and a new salary set by the department head and city manager so that the employee's new pay in the lower classification is below the employee's old pay, except in a nondisciplinary demotion, upon the recommendation of the department head, the city manager may continue the salary at the rate of pay allocated for the new position. If an employee fails to successfully complete his probationary period following a promotion, he shall be reinstated in his former position and pay or in a position in the same class as his former position. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000; Ord. No. 2001-06, § 1, 3-1-2001) Sec. 62-103. - Part-time employee. The pay plan established by this article is for full-time service. Any employee appointed for less than full-time service shall be paid at a rate determined by the city manager. Any employee appointed for less than full-time service shall not be eligible for city fringe benefits (ex. employee insurance, disability, retirement, etc…). (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000; Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 6-2-2011) Sec. 62-104. - Salary schedule. (a) Each city employee will be placed in the level to which his job is assigned. (b) At least annually, department heads will evaluate all employees during a time approved by the mayor and board of aldermen, and will make a recommendation to the city manager for salary merit adjustments. (c) Each employee may receive a merit increase according to the performance evaluation and overall pay increase approved by the mayor and board of aldermen for employees. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Secs. 62-105—62-140. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - APPOINTMENT; PROBATIONARY PERIOD; SEPARATIONS; REINSTATEMENTS
Sec. 62-141. - Employment opportunities. The city personnel officer shall publicize opportunities for employment with the city governmental unit, including the salary ranges and employment qualifications for positions to be filled. Each department head shall be responsible for assisting the personnel officer in recruiting qualified applicants to fill vacancies in his department. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-142. - Applications. (a) As a general policy, in order not to lose competent applicants, the city personnel department will accept applications at any time, whether or not a vacancy has been announced. As a result of a single application, a candidate shall be considered for all classes of positions in which his principal qualifications might be profitably used. (b) Each applicant for a position within the city government shall make application on a standard application form approved by the city manager. (c) The personnel officer may reject an application that indicates that the applicant is deficient in any of the requirements specified in the class specification or recruitment notice. An applicant may also be rejected for the practice, or attempted practice, of fraud or deception in the completion of his application, or if his past record of employment is determined to be unsatisfactory by the personnel officer. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-143. - Qualifications; evaluations. City employees shall meet the employment standards established by the position classification plan and such other reasonable minimum standards as to character, aptitude, ability to meet the public and physical condition as may be established by the personnel officer with the advice and recommendations of the department heads, provided, such minimum standards are necessary for satisfactory job performance and do not discriminate against any race, sex, nationality or religion. Discrimination in the employment of any person who is an applicant for a merit system position because of race, creed, color, sex, political affiliation or national origin shall be prohibited. The personnel officer shall review all applications to determine whether the applicant meets the qualifications established for the position. Oral interviews may be conducted by the personnel officer and/or department head. With the approval of the department head and the personnel officer, fingerprinting, check of arrest records, physical examination or other background checks may be required if deemed a factor in job performance. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-144. - Appointments generally. (a) The positions designated by resolution of the board of aldermen as department heads shall be appointed by the board of aldermen from eligible lists submitted by the personnel officer. (b) Whenever a vacancy exists in city employment, applications of all qualified applicants for the position shall be forwarded by the personnel officer to the department head for his review. The department head shall appoint the person best qualified for the position and recommend the salary to be paid. The personnel officer shall then allocate the position to a proper class in the classification plan. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-145. - Substitute appointments. The appointing authority (which shall be the department head) may approve a substitute appointment of a city employee to temporarily fill a position with a higher classification. No such substitute appointment shall continue for a period of more than six months. If the employee serves in the substitute capacity for five working days or longer, he shall be paid at the minimum rate of the pay grade assigned to the substitute position, or one pay step above his regular salary, whichever is higher. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-146. - Probationary period. (a) Any person, other than employees with an employment contract, appointed to a full-time permanent position shall serve a probationary period of one year. Employees serving a probationary period following initial employment in a permanent position shall receive all of the benefits provided in accordance with this chapter, with the following exceptions, or as otherwise provided: (1) A full-time employee may accumulate vacation leave, but shall not be permitted to take vacation leave until such employee has been employed for a period of six months, unless the denial of such leave shall create an unusual hardship. Vacation leave may be granted to such employee only with the approval of the department head. (2) An employee, if dismissed during the probationary period, shall not be eligible for terminal pay for accumulated vacation leave, nor shall he be entitled to exercise the right to appeal his dismissal. (b) Employees who receive a promotion shall serve a one-year probationary period following such promotion, and during such probationary period, such employee shall continue to receive all benefits provided in accordance with this chapter and under supplementary rules and regulations, including the right of appeal; however, during such probationary period, such employee may be reinstated to his former position without cause and without any right of appeal. (c) Before the end of the probationary period, the department head shall indicate in writing to the personnel officer: (1) That he has discussed with the employee the employee's accomplishments, failures, strengths and weaknesses; (2) Whether the employee is performing satisfactory work; (3) Whether the employee should be retained in the position; (4) Whether the employee should be given a merit salary increase; (5) Whether the employee, if a new appointee, should be discharged; or (6) Whether the employee, if on probation following a promotion, should be reinstated in his former class. (d) A new appointee may be dismissed at any time during the probationary period if the appointing authority determines that the employee is incapable of satisfactorily performing his assigned duties. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-147. - Separations. An employee may be separated from city government service by any of the following methods: (1) Notice of resignation, reemployment. To resign in good standing, an employee shall give his department head at least 14 calendar days' prior written notice. Failure to comply with such requirement shall be entered on the employee's personnel records and may be grounds for refusal of reemployment. Any employee who resigns shall not be eligible for reemployment with the city unless the city manager determines that exceptional circumstances exist to warrant reemployment. In accordance with section 62-225(d), any employee who resigns without giving at least 14 days' prior written notice shall not be entitled to receive payment for any accrued annual leave. (2) Compulsory resignation. An employee who, without valid reason, fails to report to work for three consecutive days without authorized leave shall be separated from the payroll and his absence shall be reported as a compulsory resignation. Such an employee may not be eligible for reemployment with the city. (3) Layoffs. The term "layoff" means the termination of employment of an employee when, for any valid reason, it may be necessary to abolish one or more positions, or reduce the number of employees in the city service. Layoff does not reflect discredit upon the service of the employee. Prior to the layoff, the department head shall consider work records, employee evaluation ratings and length of service, and shall make recommendations to the city manager and the board of aldermen as to which employees shall be laid off. The chief basis of the layoff decision shall be the relative competence of the employees for the job that remains. In choosing between two employees, the employee most competent for the job that remains shall be retained. If it is found that two or more persons in the organizational unit in which a layoff is to be made have equal ratings as determined by review of employee records and evaluation ratings, the last employee to enter the service shall be the first to be laid off. No permanent career employee shall be laid off while another person in a classified position is employed on a temporary basis in the same class if the employee is willing to accept the temporary or part-time work. Permanent career employees shall be notified in writing at least 14 calendar days prior to the effective date of such layoff, and shall be informed of their right of appeal such layoff under section 62-183. (4) Loss of job requirement. Any employee who is unable to adequately perform his job because of loss of a necessary license or other requirement shall be separated by a layoff or placed in another position for which he may be qualified at the discretion of the department head and city manager. (5) Dismissal. An employee in a classified service may be terminated from city employment for cause. (6) Death. When a permanent employee dies while in the classified service, his estate shall be eligible to receive the accumulated annual leave and any other compensation due the deceased employee. (7) Retirement. The provisions of the retirement ordinance shall apply. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-148. - Credit of sick leave and retirement. A city employee who has been separated from city government service because of a reduction in the work force, or who has resigned while in good standing, shall be credited with his previously accrued sick leave if he is reinstated within one year. If the reinstated employee shall have continued to be a member of either the employee's retirement system or the peace officer's benefit and retirement fund, he shall receive full credit for all accrued contributions up to the time of his separation. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-149. - Reinstatement of seniority. Except as provided in section 62-148, when a city employee, upon proper notice to terminate his employment, is rehired within 12 months of his resignation, after 24 continuous months of employment, such employee shall have his seniority reinstated. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-150. - Limitation of employment of relatives. (a) A department head, or any person serving in a supervisory capacity, is prohibited from hiring an immediate family member, or a member of such supervisor's immediate household, into a position within their line of authority. Such department head or supervisor is further prohibited from hiring an immediate family member of any person currently serving as mayor or city alderman. The term "immediate family member" means spouse, son, daughter, parent, grandparent, grandchild, brother, sister, mother-in-law, father-in-law and any other person living in the same household. (b) Immediate family members of employees of the city shall not be employed if such employment will result in one immediate family member supervising another immediate family member, or where one immediate family member occupies a position that has an influence over the other immediate family member's employment, promotion, salary administration and other related management or personnel. Specific work site or duty considerations may warrant transfer of city employees who subsequently become related by marriage. If a transfer is not possible, then the city manager may terminate the employee with the least seniority, or the parties may agree on which employee shall leave city employment. Application of this provision will be limited to those circumstances where the employer's interests outweigh the adverse impact, if any, upon the affected employees. (c) Notwithstanding any of the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, any person who is a relative of the mayor, member of the board of aldermen or the city manager, who is an employee of the city at the time such mayor, member of the board of aldermen or city manager is elected or appointed to office, may continue in his employment with the city. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-151. - Examination by health care provider. The city may direct any city employee to be examined by a health care provider of the city's choosing, including, but not limited to, a specific psychologist, physician or psychiatrist. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-152. - Disability. (a) If it is determined by the city, with information received from a health care provider, that an employee cannot perform the essential functions of his job due to a disability, and the employee goes on disability, the employee shall be considered to be on an unpaid leave of absence. Such leave of absence shall run concurrently with the leave requirements of the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA). FMLA shall begin immediately upon an employee going on disability leave. (b) The city will continue to pay all health insurance premiums and contributions to retirement for a disabled employee as it does for all employees for a period of six months from the date the employee goes on disability, and shall be considered shortterm disability. (c) If, after a period of six months from the date that an employee goes on disability, an employee suffers from a disability which prevents him from performing the essential functions of his position, even with reasonable accommodation, the city manager shall then have the option of: (1) Terminating the employee's employment for inability to perform the job, and the employee shall then be entitled to all benefits as outlined in the city's longterm disability insurance policy. (2) Holding the employee's position for a period of up to an additional three months past the original six months of shortterm disability if the employee can show medical proof that there is a likelihood that the employee will be able to return to work within the additional three-month period. (Note: The city manager shall specify a specific time when the employee shall return to work which shall not exceed three additional months past the original six-month period. The time specified shall be based on the medical documentation indicating when the employee would be able to return to work. The city shall have the right to have the employee examined by its own doctor to determine if there is a likelihood of the employee returning to work.) The employee shall be required to pay 100 percent of all insurance premium costs, and no contribution shall be made to the retirement system for the employee during such period. If the employee does not return to work within the time approved by the city manager past the original six-month period of shortterm disability, then the employee shall be terminated for inability to perform his job. The employee shall be entitled to all benefits as outlined in the city's longterm disability insurance policy. (d) An employee on shortterm disability shall continue to accrue sick time, vacation time and seniority for a period of 30 days. The employee shall not lose his vacation and/or sick time, but he shall not accrue any additional time until he comes back to work full-time. After one month on disability, an employee's seniority shall be frozen. (e) An employee shall cooperate with the city's disability carrier to determine the limitations imposed by such employee's medical condition, and shall cooperate to design, if appropriate, reasonable accommodation for the essential functions of his job. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-153. - Family and medical leave. (a) City of Acworth will comply with the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 ("FMLA") in accordance with the applicable statutes regulations, and Department of Labor Guidelines ("FMLA Statutes"). This FMLA policy is intended to explain the FMLA statutes, and any terms herein used that are defined in the FMLA statutes carry the same definitions as in the FMLA statutes. This policy neither adds to nor subtracts from the rights and obligations under the FMLA statutes. (1) Eligibility. Provided that the city employs at least 50 employees within 75 miles of the requesting employee's worksite, all full-time and part-time employees who have been employed by the city for one year (not including any period of employment preceding any break in service of at least seven years) and who have worked at least 1,250 hours during the 12-month period preceding a request for leave, are eligible for FMLA leave for the following reasons: (i) The birth of the employee's child and to care for the newborn child; (ii) The placement with the employee of a child for adoption or foster care; (iii) The care for the employee's spouse, child or parent with a serious health condition; (iv) The care of the employee's own serious health condition; (v) The care of a covered servicemember who is a spouse, child (any age), parent, or next of kin; and (vi) Attention to matters arising from an exigency of deployment of a spouse, child or parent in the National Guard or Armed Forces Reserves. Covered servicemember means any current member of the US Armed Forces, including National Guard or Reserves, who is undergoing medical treatment, recuperation or therapy, is otherwise in outpatient status, or is otherwise on the temporary disability retired list, for a serious injury or illness incurred in the line of duty on active duty that may render the individual medically unfit to perform the duties of the individual's office, grade, rank, or rating. Next of kin means the nearest blood relative, not including spouse, parent, son, or daughter, in the following order of priority: A) Blood relatives granted legal custody of the covered servicemember, B) brothers and sisters, C) grandparents, D) aunts and uncles, E) and first cousins, unless the covered servicemember has specifically designated in writing another blood relative for purposes of this leave, which relative shall be deemed the only blood relative for this purpose. Documentation may be required to establish the qualifying relationship. Exigency of deployment. An exigency of deployment is a call to active duty in support of a contingency operation pursuant to: 10 USC §§ 688, 12301(a), 12302, 12304, 12305, or 12406 or 10 USC Chapter 15 or any other provision of law during a war or during a national emergency declared by the President or Congress, and only in connection with a federal call to duty, unless a state call to duty is pursuant to one of the foregoing provisions or order of the President, and regardless of whether the call to duty is initiated by a state or the federal government, provided that one of the following exists: a. Short notice deployment. Leave for up to seven days may be taken if the servicemember receives seven or fewer days notice of the deployment. b. Military events and related activities. Leave may be granted to attend official military ceremony or program or to attend family support or assistance programs and informational meetings sponsored or promoted by the military, military service organizations, or the American Red Cross, provided that all of the foregoing relate to the call to active duty. c. Childcare and school activities. Leave to arrange, in connection with the child (including stepchildren and adopted or foster children who are under the age of 18 or are age 18 or older and are incapable of self-care) of the servicemember, for alternative or changed childcare or schooling, to provide urgent or immediate care (as opposed to routine or regular care), or to attend meetings with school or childcare staff when the need to make such arrangements or provide such care arises from the call to active duty. d. Financial and legal arrangements. Leave to make or update financial arrangements in connection with the servicemember's absence or, during active duty status and for a period of 90 days following the termination of the servicemembers' active duty status, to act as the servicemembers representative in connection with obtaining, arranging, or appealing military service benefits. e. Counseling. To attend counseling by someone other than a healthcare provider for the employee, the covered servicemember, or the child of the servicemember in connection with the call to active duty. f. Rest and recuperation. Leave for up to five days in connection with each instance in which the servicemember is on short term leave for rest and recuperation. g. Post-deployment activities. Leave to attend arrival ceremonies, reintegration meetings and events, and any other official ceremony or program sponsored by the military within 90 days of termination of the servicemember's active duty status or to address issues arising from the servicemember's death. h. Additional activities. Leave to address other events which arise out of the call to active duty, provided that the city and the employee agree that such leave qualifies as an exigency and agree on the timing and length of the leave. (2) Required Use of Paid Leave. Employees will be required to apply all paid and unpaid leave (including annual leave time, compensatory time, etc.) concurrent with FMLA leave. Employees receiving pay for the use of paid leave will be required to comply with all of the requirements of City of Acworth paid leave policies. An employee's accrued sick leave, workers' compensation and/or disability leave will not be applied towards FMLA leave if the employee is taking FMLA leave for any purpose other than that allowed under those policies and provided further that an employee will not be required to take paid leave concurrent with FMLA leave if the employee is receiving income benefits under a City of Acworth group disability plan or under workers' compensation law. (3) Serious health condition. A serious health condition means an illness, injury, impairment, or physical or mental condition that results in an incapacity (i.e., the individual is unable to care for themselves or unable to perform the essential functions of the job or, if a child, unable to attend school). A serious health condition must also involve one of the following: a. Hospital care. At least one night's stay in a hospital, hospice or residential medical care facility, including any period of incapacity or subsequent treatment in connection with or consequent to the inpatient care. b. Absence plus treatment. A period of incapacity of more than three consecutive calendar days (including any subsequent treatment or period of incapacity relating to the same condition), that also involves either (1) treatment two or more times within 30 days of the onset of the incapacity, provided that the first in-person visit with the healthcare provider occurs within seven days of the onset of incapacity, by, or under the supervision of or pursuant to referral by a health care provider, or (2) treatment by a health care provider on at least one occasion, provided that the first in-person visit with the healthcare provider occurs within seven days of the onset of incapacity, which results in a regimen of continuing treatment under the supervision of a health care provider. a regimen of continuing treatment does not include the taking of over-the-counter medications such as aspirin, antihistamines, or salves, or bed-rest, drinking fluids, exercise, and other similar activities that can be initiated without a visit to a health care provider. c. Pregnancy. Any period of incapacity due to pregnancy or for prenatal care. d. Chronic condition requiring treatment. A chronic condition which (1) requires periodic visits (at least twice a year) for treatment by, or under the direct supervision of, a health care provider, (2) continues over an extended period of time (including recurring episodes of a single underlying condition), and (3) may cause episodic rather than a continuing period of incapacity (examples: asthma, diabetes, epilepsy). e. Permanent/long-term conditions requiring supervision. A period of incapacity which is permanent or long-term due to a condition for which treatment may not be effective. The individual must be under the continuing supervision of, but need not be receiving active treatment by, a health care provider (examples: Alzheimer's, a severe stroke, or the terminal stages of a disease). f. Any period of absence to receive multiple treatments (including any necessary recovery period) by a health care provider or by a provider of health care services under orders of, or on referral by, a health care provider, either for restorative surgery after an accident or other injury, or for a condition that would likely result in a period of incapacity of more than three consecutive calendar days in the absence of medical intervention or treatment, such as cancer (chemotherapy, radiation, etc.), severe arthritis (physical therapy), and kidney disease (dialysis). (b) Notice required of employee. When use of FMLA leave is foreseeable, an employee must provide 30 days advance notice to the City. If the employee becomes aware of the need for leave less than 30 days in advance, notice must be provided as soon as practicable. If an employee fails to provide 30 days advance notice, and it is determined that use of FMLA leave was reasonably foreseeable, then FMLA leave may be denied until 30 days have elapsed from the date notice was given or should have been given. If additional FMLA leave is needed for qualifying reason previously approved, the employee should specifically refer to that reason or specifically request FMLA leave. When scheduling medical treatment, the employee should consult with the immediate supervisor and department head regarding the schedule so as to minimize undue disruption caused by the employee's absence(s). If a leave request in connection with an exigency of deployment is not accompanied by a copy of the military orders or other acceptable military documentation, such documentation will be requested in connection with the first request for leave for each deployment. (c) Medical certification. If an employee is taking FMLA leave, the leave request should be accompanied by a medical certification of the need for leave on a form approved by the city. If the leave request does not include a medical certification, the city will request, in writing, that the employee provide medical certification to the city on or before the later of (1) fifteen (15) calendar days after the written request from the city for the certification, or (2) the commencement of the leave. Failure to submit the certification may result in denial of FMLA leave or delay of the leave until the certification is submitted. Additional medical opinions may be obtained by the city at its option and will be binding in accordance with the FMLA statutes. The city requires that the employee provide subsequent medical certifications on the approved form. Generally, the re-certifications will be required no more often than every 30 days. However, recertification may be required more or less frequently in accordance with the FMLA Statutes. (d) Medical benefits. The city will continue all health care benefits for the duration of FMLA leave, provided the employee pays the employee's portion of the health care benefit premiums. Any employee on FMLA leave will be required to continue to pay health care benefit premiums during the time the employee is on FMLA leave, by submitting to the city at the beginning of each month an amount equal to the monthly premiums that would have been deducted from the employee's pay were the employee not on FMLA leave. The city may cancel all health care benefits if the employee's premium payment is more than 30 days late if the city has provided 15 days' written notice to the employee prior to cancellation. The city will continue health benefits during these 30 days. If an employee fails to return to work after the employee's FMLA leave entitlement has been exhausted or expires, the city will be entitled under certain circumstances to recover the health care benefit premiums paid by the city during the period of unpaid FMLA leave. An employee must return to work for a minimum of thirty days in order to qualify as "returning to work." (e) (1) 12-month period. Eligible employees are entitled to take up to twelve weeks of FMLA leave during a rolling 12-month period measured backward from the date an employee uses any FMLA leave. An employee's entitlement to leave for a birth or placement for adoption or foster care expires at the end of the 12-month period beginning on the date of the birth or placement. Spouses who are both employed by the city are limited to a combined total of 12 weeks of leave during any 12-month period if the leave is taken for the birth of the employee's child or the placement of a child with the employee for adoption or foster care. (2) An eligible employee is entitled to 26 weeks of covered servicemember leave on a per covered servicemember per injury/ illness basis, provided that no more than 26 weeks of FMLA leave for any reason (although no more than 12 weeks may be taken for a qualifying reason other than servicemember leave) may be taken during a single 12-month period as measured from the start of each such period of covered servicemember leave. If both spouses intend to care for a covered servicemember and are both employed by the city, they are limited to a combined total of 26 weeks of leave if the leave is in connection with covered servicemember leave and is limited as set forth in (e)(1), above. (f) Reinstatement. On return from FMLA leave, the employee is entitled to be returned to the same position the employee held when leave commenced, or to an equivalent position with equivalent benefits pay, and other terms and conditions of employment, provided the employee is able to perform the essential functions of the position. An employee has no greater right to reinstatement or to other benefits and conditions of employment than if the employee had been continuously employed during the leave period. (g) Return to work certification. An employee with a serious health condition who has been out on FMLA leave must provide certification that the employee is fit to return to work. The employee will be provided with a list of the essential functions of his/her job with the city response to a request for FMLA leave. For certain positions, an employee on intermittent leave may be required to submit a fitness-for-duty certification every 30 days due to safety concerns. The employer may delay restoration until the certification is provided. (h) Intermittent and reduced schedule leave. FMLA leave for the serious medical condition of the employee or a family member, for an exigency of deployment, or covered servicemember, may be taken in increments or result in a reduced schedule of work, provided (except in the case of an exigency of deployment) the need for intermittent reduced-schedule leave is certified by the health care provider on the approved medical certification form. If an employee needs leave intermittently or on a reduced leave schedule for planned medical treatment, then the employee must make a reasonable effort to schedule the treatment so as not to disrupt unduly the employer's operations. In addition, if an employee takes intermittent or reduced-schedule leave, the city has the right to assign the employee to an alternative position with equivalent pay and benefits if the alternative position better accommodates the need for such leave. Regardless of the manner in which any paid leave is taken by an employee pursuant to city policies, leave may not be deducted from an employee's "bank" of FMLA leave in increments of time that are greater than one hour. (i) Termination of employment. Unless otherwise required by law, employment with the city will normally terminate if the employee does not return to work after the maximum amount of FMLA leave has been taken. (j) Key employees. At the time FMLA leave is requested, the city will designate an employee as a "key employee" if that employee is among the highest paid ten percent of city employees at the time the FMLA leave is requested. (1) The key employee will be given a written notice at the time FMLA leave is requested, or as soon as practicable thereafter, that the employee qualifies as a key employee. In addition to informing the employee that he/she qualifies as a key employee, the city will also inform the employee of the potential consequences with respect to reinstatement and maintenance of health benefits. (2) When the city makes a determination that substantial and grievous economic injury to its operations will result if a key employee who has requested or is using FMLA leave is reinstated, the city will notify the employee as soon as practicable in writing of its determination, stating that it intends to deny restoration to employment on completion of the FMLA leave (notice of intent). This notice of intent will explain the basis for the city's determination and will provide the employee a reasonable time in which to return to work, taking into account the circumstances, such as the length of the leave and the urgency of the need for the employee to return. (3) If an employee does not return to work in response to the notice of intent, the employee will continue to be entitled to maintenance of health benefits during the remainder of the FMLA leave, provided that the requirements of subsection(c), above, are met, and the city will not recover its cost of health premiums. (4) After the notice of intent is given to the employee, the employee will remain entitled to request reinstatement at the end of the leave period. The city will then again determine whether there will be substantial and grievous economic injury from reinstatement, based on the facts at that time. (5) Any written notices given to a key employee must be either sent by certified mail or given in person. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000; Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 6-2-2011) Secs. 62-154—62-180. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - DISCIPLINARY ACTIONS, APPEALS, GRIEVANCES
Sec. 62-181. - Types of disciplinary action. Except as otherwise provided by state statutes, the provisions of this section shall govern disciplinary actions affecting employees in the classified service of the city. (1) Dismissal. Employees in the classified service of the city may be dismissed for cause. A written statement specifically setting forth the reasons for the proposed dismissal shall be furnished to the affected employee by his department head, and a copy shall be filed with the personnel officer prior to the effective date of the proposed dismissal. The employee will be permitted to respond to the reasons for dismissal prior to a final decision being made by the department head. Such an employee shall have the right of appeal as provided in section 62-183. (2) Suspension. A department head may, for disciplinary purposes, suspend without pay any employee in his department for a length of time as he considers appropriate, not exceeding 30 working days. Except as otherwise permitted by law, a written statement of the reasons for such suspension shall be furnished to the affected employee by their department head, and a copy shall be filed with the personnel officer prior to the effective date of the suspension. The employee will be permitted to respond to the reasons for such suspension prior to a final decision being made by the department head. Permanent career employees shall be notified of their right of appeal under section 62-183. (3) Demotion. A department head may reduce the salary of an employee within the range provided in the pay plan, or demote the employee for cause to a lower grade. A written statement of the reasons for any such demotion shall be furnished to the affected employee by his department head, and a copy shall be filed with the personnel officer prior to a final decision being made by the department head. The employee will be permitted to respond to the reasons for such demotion prior to a final decision being made by the department head. Permanent career employees shall be notified of their right of appeal under section 62-183. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-182. - Reasons for disciplinary action. Reasons for disciplinary action against a city employee, as set forth in section 62-181, shall include, but are not limited to, the following: (1) Insubordination or uncooperative attitude which tends to lower discipline and morale. (2) Failure to do work at an acceptable level of competence as determined by the department head which may include excessive tardiness, lost time or inefficiency. (3) Conviction of a felony or crime involving moral turpitude. (4) Absence without leave. (5) Abuse, neglect or misuse of city property or vehicles. (6) Willfully giving false, incomplete or misleading statements, or withholding information from supervisors, officials, the public or boards. (7) Violation of federal or state law, city ordinances, administrative regulations or departmental rules. (8) Using, possessing, selling, being under the influence of or testing positive for the use of alcohol or controlled substances while on duty. (9) Discovery of a false statement in an application that had not been previously detected. (10) Acceptance of gratuities in conflict with section 62-10. (11) Physical or mental disability that precludes satisfactory performance of duties. (12) Refusal to be examined by an authorized licensed physician, psychologist or other health care provider when so directed. (13) Political activity in conflict with the provisions of this chapter. (14) Acts during or outside of duty hours that are incompatible with the public service. (15) Discourteous treatment of the public or other employees. (16) Failure to follow the proper chain of command. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-183. - Appeals. (a) Eligibility. Any permanent status career employee, other than a department head as defined in section 62-3, who has been demoted for cause, suspended or dismissed, or who alleges charges of discrimination in promotional procedure or layoff in violation of the established layoff policy shall have the right of appeal to the city manager, or to a hearing officer, as provided in this section, if the city manager is not available, as a result of absence, disqualification or otherwise. The employee or his authorized agent shall file such an appeal in writing with the office of the city manager within five business days of the effective date of such action, and shall file a copy of such appeal at the same time with his appointing authority. (b) Hearing. The city manager shall set a time and place for a hearing on an appeal, and shall notify the employee thereof. The hearing shall be held at a meaningful time, to the extent practicable, which shall be not less than seven nor more than 30 calendar days after receipt of the employee's request for a hearing; provided, however, that neither this section, nor any notice issued pursuant to this section, shall give an employee the right to a hearing within a specified time or on a particular date. (c) Decision final. The decision of the city manager or hearing officer on an appeal under this section shall be final. (d) Notification of results. The employee filing an appeal under this section shall be notified promptly in writing by the city clerk of the final determination in regard to the disciplinary action. (e) Conduct of appeals. Appeals under this section shall be conducted as follows: (1) The employee may be represented by an attorney. (2) In the absence of special circumstances and permission from the department head, the employee may not prepare for an appeal while on duty. (3) Employees shall be assured freedom from reprisal for using the appeal procedures. (4) Appeal hearings shall be informal, and the technical rules of evidence shall not apply. (5) All performance related documents, including, hut not limited to, evaluations, disciplinary actions, letters of commendation and training records that are in an employee's personnel file shall be made part of the hearing record. (6) Witness lists and documentary evidence shall be exchanged to each side prior to the hearing. (7) If the city manager is not available due to absence, disqualification or otherwise to hear an appeal of an employee, then a hearing officer shall be appointed by the mayor and board of aldermen to hear and decide such appeal. The hearing officer may be, but shall not be required to be, the mayor, member of the board of aldermen, an employee of the city or administrative officer of another city. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-184. - Grievances. (a) Policy. It shall be the policy of the city government to foster employee satisfaction, and to give careful consideration and attention to any complaint. For the purposes of this section, a grievance shall be considered to be any matter concerning an employee's status or consideration of employment for which appeal to the city manager is not provided in this chapter. (b) Nongrievable issues. The following shall be employment issues which are not grievable: (1) Disciplinary action taken against a noncovered employee (e.g., a department head, probationary employee, part-time employee or reserve employee). (2) Oral or written reprimands. (3) Shift changes. (4) Temporary work assignments not involving a reduction in rank or pay. (5) Changes in budget or organizational structure. (6) Decisions, policies, practices, resolutions, ordinances or other actions taken by the board of aldermen. (c) General procedures. (1) If a grievance is the result of an action or decision of a management official above the first line supervisor, the initial grievance may be submitted in writing to that person, otherwise all grievances shall be submitted in writing to the employee's immediate supervisor. (2) For each grievance, a file will be maintained of all written material submitted by the employee or management for use at each step of the grievance procedure. (3) Written grievances must explain the complaint and what remedy is being sought. (4) Employees shall not use the grievance procedure to complain about a proper order, directive, regulation, policy or administrative decision issued by a supervisor or management official who is acting within their delegated authority. If there is reasonable evidence to show that proper authority has been exceeded, the grievance procedure may be used to challenge such issue. (5) "Workdays," as used in the grievance procedure, mean Monday—Friday. (d) Filing. (1) An employee may submit a grievance on a continuing condition or action at any time. (2) Grievances relating to specific one-time or noncontinuing occurrences must be submitted within five workdays from the date the matter arose, otherwise, such grievance will not be accepted. All grievances shall be in writing. (3) Every effort shall be made to find an acceptable solution to a grievance at the lowest possible level of supervision. a. Step 1. Upon receiving a grievance from an employee submitting a grievance for the first time, the supervisor must discuss the grievance informally with the employee within five working days of the submission of such grievance. The employee will be given a decision in writing within five working days after such discussion. b. Step 2. If the employee is not satisfied with the decision in step 1, or the supervisor fails to comply with the time limits established in step 1, the employee may continue the grievance by submitting the grievance to his supervisor's immediate superior, if any, in the administrative service. Such grievance shall be submitted within three days of the supervisor's decision or the expiration of the time period listed in step 1. The next level supervisor shall discuss the grievance with the employee and other appropriate persons within five working days after the grievance is filed with the supervisor. The supervisor shall render his decision and comments in writing, and return such decision and comments to the employee within five workdays after meeting with the employee. If the employee does not agree with the decision reached, or the supervisor fails to provide resolution of the grievance, the employee may continue following the appeal procedure and time lines up to the city manager. c. Step 3. The city manager, upon receiving the grievance, shall discuss the grievance with the employee and other appropriate persons within ten workdays of receipt of the grievance. The city manager shall render his decision and comments in writing, and return such decision and comments to the employee within five workdays after meeting with the employee. The decisions of the city manager shall be final. The city manager may extend the time for discussing the grievance with the employee and/or rendering a decision on the grievance within his discretion. Note: The appeals procedure outlined in section 62-183 shall be used for cases involving demotion, suspension, dismissal, layoff in violation of established policy or charges of discrimination in promotion procedures. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-185. - Physical and psychological testing for fitness for duty. (a) Whenever a department head has reasonable cause to believe that an employee within his department may not be physically or psychologically fit for duty, or may be a threat to the health or safety of other employees or the public, based upon an employee's conduct either within or outside the work place, such department head, with the approval of the city manager, may require such employee to undergo physical or psychological testing by a licensed physician or psychologist selected by the city at the city's expense. (b) Performance behaviors which may lead a supervisor or department head to suspect an employee needs psychological or physical assistance may include, but are not limited to, the following: (1) A series of sustained citizen or fellow employee complaints. (2) Repeated complaints of the same nature. (3) Involvement in a shooting, accident or incident which results in a death or serious injury to any of the parties involved. (4) Involvement in other traumatic incidents, professional or personal, that may result in the inability of the employee to perform all of his job duties in a satisfactory manner. (5) Abrupt changes in expected responses and/or behavior which may be indicative of severe emotional disturbances, such as continuous tardiness; absenteeism; sleeping on duty; excessive impatience; violent reaction to supervisors, fellow employees or the public; overeating or not eating; poor personal appearance or hygiene; physical symptoms of alcohol or drug use; or other unusual behavior. (c) An employee who is directed to undergo such physical or psychological testing shall execute such authorizations as may be necessary for the city to receive any records and reports relating to such testing from the physician or psychologist performing the test and to further authorize such physician or psychologist to discuss the employee's physical or psychological condition with the employee's department head and city manager. The employee shall also receive a copy of any reports or records which the city receives from such physician or psychologist. Any employee who is directed to undergo such physical or psychological testing and refuses to do so shall be guilty of insubordination and shall be subject to disciplinary action up to and including termination of employment. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Secs. 62-186—62-220. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - ATTENDANCE; LEAVE
Sec. 62-221. - Hours of work. (a) The established work week for full-time employees in the career service of the city, other than certified police officers and detention officers, shall be not less than 40 hours, and shall be the same for all persons, other than certified police officers and detention officers. The established work period for hourly certified police officers and detention officers shall be 14 days. Hourly certified police officers and detention officers shall be entitled to overtime compensation for all hours worked in excess of 86 hours during any such work period. (b) Any employee (other than a certified police officer or detention officer) whose regular work schedule is less than 40 hours per week but whose position is year-round is classified as a permanent employee working part-time. (c) Any employee (other than a certified police officer or detention officer) whose regular work schedule is less than 40 hours per week and whose job is only for a temporary/seasonal basis shall be classified as a part-time temporary/seasonal employee. (d) An hourly certified police officer or detention officer whose regular work schedule is 48 hours or more but less than 80 hours in a 14 consecutive day period, but whose position is year-round is classified as a permanent employee working part-time. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000; Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 6-2-2011) Sec. 62-222. - Attendance records; authorization of leave. Each department head shall be responsible for the punctual attendance of all employees under his administrative supervision, and shall keep such attendance records as shall be required by the city manager. Leave shall be authorized in units of days or hours only. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-223. - Overtime. (a) Supervisors shall make every attempt to arrange the work schedules of their employees so as to accomplish the required work within the standard workday. Employees shall be required to work overtime in emergencies, or when their supervisor determines that overtime is necessary for the department to carry out its functions and/or finish a project. The term "overtime work" means work performed by an employee at the direction of a department head or his authorized representative that exceeds the established work week of the employee. (b) Employees covered by the provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act shall be paid for overtime in compliance with such act. Other employees who are required to work overtime may receive compensatory time off at a time that will least obstruct departmental operation, or be compensated at a rate set by the board of aldermen. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-224. - Holidays. (a) Eligibility. All full-time permanent employees shall be eligible for holiday leave for the following days, and such other days as may be designated by specific action of the board of aldermen: New Year's Day, Martin Luther King, Jr. Day, Good Friday, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, the Friday after Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve, Christmas Day and one personal holiday, with the supervisor's approval. Permanent employees working less than full-time shall also be eligible for such holidays, with pay, for their regular number of hours at their regular rate of pay. In order to receive pay for an observed holiday, an employee must not have been absent without leave on the workday immediately preceding or immediately after the holiday. (b) Holiday on Saturday or Sunday. When a holiday falls on a Saturday, the previous Friday shall be designated as the holiday. When a holiday falls on a Sunday, the following Monday shall be designated as the holiday. (c) Holiday workday. All eligible employees who are required to work on a scheduled holiday, excluding the personal holiday, shall be paid for the holiday at their regular rate of pay, plus each employee shall be paid at 1½ his regular rate of pay for the hours actually worked on the scheduled holiday. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000; Ord. No. 2004-36, § 1, 9-2-2004; Ord. No. 2012-04, § 1, 3-1-2012) Sec. 62-225. - Annual leave (vacation). (a) Eligibility. All permanent employees working full-time, and career employees serving temporarily in substitute or acting positions, shall be eligible to accrue vacation leave as outlined in subsection (b) of this section. (b) Accrual. Full-time eligible employees shall accrue vacation leave pursuant to the following schedule: (1) Upon beginning employment to the completion of one full year of work, two hours per bi-weekly pay period, or major portion thereof. (2) Upon beginning the second year of employment and until completing nine full years of work, four hours per bi-weekly pay period, or major portion thereof. (3) Upon beginning the tenth year of employment and until completing 20 full years of work, six hours per bi-weekly pay period, or major portion thereof. (4) Upon beginning the 21st year of employment and every year thereafter, eight hours per bi-weekly pay period, or major portion thereof. (c) Permanent employees working part time shall be eligible to earn vacation leave at one-half the rate stated in (b) above provided they are working the following minimum hours: Part-time employee working from a 40-hour week—Minimum 16 hours week. Part-time certified police officer/detention officer—Minimum 48 hours in a 14-day period. (d) Temporary/seasonal or other substitute employees are not eligible for vacation leave. (e) Vacation leave shall accrue from the date of employment. Upon each employee's anniversary date, they shall be allowed to carry over the vacation hours earned in the previous year, but no more than that amount. Carried-over vacation hours must be used by the employee's anniversary date. At no time shall an employee have accrued more than the vacation hours earned from a previous year and the current year. All unused vacation hours in excess of what is allowed to be accrued shall be forfeited. (f) Time for using vacation leave. Vacation leave assignments will be made in accordance with the preference of the employee, where possible; however, vacation leave must be taken at the convenience of the department, and the department head's decision as to when leave may or may not be taken will be final. Seniority will be a major factor when preparing leave schedules. (g) Transfer to another employee. Upon a showing of exceptional circumstances, as determined and approved by the department head, an employee may transfer accrued annual leave to another employee. Any employee desiring to transfer accrued annual leave to another employee shall submit a written request to his department head, setting forth the exceptional circumstances that would justify such a transfer. Exceptional circumstances shall include, but are not limited to, unusual or extended illness of another employee or such other employee's family. (h) Resignation of employment. Employees who resign their employment with the city shall not be paid for accrued vacation leave upon their resignation unless such employee has given the city 14-days' prior written notice of such resignation. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000; Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 6-2-2011; Ord. No. 2013-19, § I, 5-16-2013; Ord. No. 2013-33, § I, 10-3-2013) Sec. 62-226. - Sick leave. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribe to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Sick leave means paid leave that may be granted to each eligible employee who, through sickness or injury, becomes incapacitated to a degree that makes it impossible for the employee to perform the duties of their position; is quarantined by a physician because they have been exposed to a contagious disease; or is absent for medical, dental or optical examination or treatment. An eligible employee may use sick time to care for their immediate family (custodial children, spouse, the employee's parents). Up to three days sick leave may be used for emergency personal leave if specifically approved by the appropriate department head. (b) Entitlement. All permanent employees, working full-time or part-time, and career employees serving temporarily in substitute or acting capacities, shall be eligible to accrue sick leave as set forth in subsection (d) of this section. Temporary/seasonal and other part-time or substitute employees shall not be eligible for sick leave. (c) On-the-job injury. (1) An employee who sustains an injury on the job must, at the time of the injury or as soon as possible after such injury, notify their supervisor on the forms provided by the city. An employee injured on the job is entitled to weekly income benefits under the City of Acworth's workers' compensation if they have more than seven days of lost time due to an injury. If the employee is out of work more than 21 consecutive days, workers' compensation will pay them for the first week. (2) The city allows an employee to use sick leave for the first week that they would not be receiving any benefits under workers' compensation. However, if the employee is out more than 21 consecutive days workers' compensation will then pay them for the first week they were absent. (3) There are two options on how an employee can handle the first week of absence: a. If the employee uses sick leave to cover the first week and they are out more than 21 consecutive days they can reimburse the city by signing the workers' compensation check over to the city and have their sick leave credited back. b. If they choose to cash the workers' compensation check and not reimburse the city they will lose the sick leave taken to cover the first week. (d) Accrual. Full-time eligible employees shall accrue sick leave at the rate of four hours per bi-weekly pay period, or major portion thereof, for a total of 104 sick leave hours per year. Permanent employees working less than full-time shall earn two hours per bi-weekly, or major portion thereof, for a total of 52 sick leave hours per year. If unused, sick leave may be carried over each year and added to previously accumulated sick leave, up to a maximum of 248 hours. Sick leave time shall accrue from the date of employment. A full time employee who has taken 64 hours or more sick leave with or without pay in one bi-weekly pay period shall not earn sick leave credit for that period. A permanent employee working part time who has taken 32 hours or more sick leave with or without pay in one bi-weekly pay period shall not earn sick leave credit for that period. (e) Reporting. An employee who is absent from work because of illness is responsible for reporting such absence to the appropriate supervisor or department head as soon as the employee is aware that they will not be coming in due to sickness and at a minimum within two hours after the designated reporting time on the day of absence, and such employee shall be expected to keep his supervisor or department head informed of his progress on a regular basis, and such leave will be charged against the employee's sick leave. Employee shall provide supervisor or department head expect leave required during absence. Where a relief employee is required in a department that must provide 24-hour sustained service, the employee must report his absence two hours before the designated reporting time. (f) Use; abuse. Sick leave shall not be considered a right an employee may use at their discretion, but a privilege not to be abused. Department heads who believe an employee is abusing the sick leave privilege may require the employee to furnish a doctor's certificate for each period of absence, regardless of the provisions set forth in subsection (g) of this section. (g) Doctor's certificate. A department head may require an employee to present him with a written statement by a licensed physician or dentist, certifying that the employee's condition prevented him from performing the duties of their position if an employee is absent from work in excess of three consecutive working days or the employee has a pattern of absence due to sickness. If a department head requires a doctor's certificate, then sick leave with pay shall only be paid to the employee if the employee submits the doctor's certificate. (h) Lack of sick leave. All employees are expected to use sick leave for its intended purpose and to accumulate sick leave so they have it when it is needed. If for some reason an employee has no accumulated sick leave but needs to be absent from work because they are sick, they must first use any vacation time they have is lieu of sick time. If the employee has no vacation time or sick time accumulated they shall be entitled to a maximum of three days off without pay, but shall provide a note from a doctor or dentist explaining the employee was under their care and the period of care (or date the employee could return to work). If the employee does not bring in the note the employee shall have been considered absent without leave and it shall be considered a voluntary quit. This provision shall only be allowed to be used by an employee once within a 12-month period. If the employee needs time off for being sick more than once in a 12-month period and the employee has no sick time or vacation time to use and the employee is absent from work then the employee shall have been considered absent without leave and it shall be considered a voluntary quit. (i) Termination of employment. An employee, upon separation from the city government service, shall not receive payment for accumulated sick leave. (j) Buy-back. Employees who have accumulated the maximum sick leave of 240 hours may, at their option, sell all sick leave that has accrued in excess of such 240 hour maximum during the calendar year to the city during the first week of December of such calendar year in exchange for an amount equal to half the employees hourly rate of pay (calculated hourly pay for salaried employees) for each hour of sick leave in excess of 240 hours. In addition, employees who have accumulated the maximum 240 hours of sick leave and who have not used any sick leave during the calendar year shall receive two full personal days of leave (equal to their scheduled workday) to be used at the employee's discretion during the following calendar year. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000; Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 6-2-2011; Ord. No. 2013-33, § II, 10-3-2013) Sec. 62-227. - Military leave. Military leave for city employees shall be governed according to the requirements of state law. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-228. - Civil leave. An employee shall be given necessary time off without loss of pay when performing jury duty or when required by proper authority to be a witness in legal proceedings, provided, such call to duty is reported in advance to the employee's department head. In order to receive full pay for the necessary time off duty, all fees received by the employee, other than meal and travel allowance, must be deposited with the fiscal officer. Employees who perform jury duty or are required to be a witness in a legal proceeding when such is required during periods when the employee is otherwise in a nonduty status will be permitted to retain all fees and allowances received. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-229. - Maternity leave. Maternity leave shall be granted to merit system employees upon written request filed by the employee at least two weeks prior to the effective date, unless emergency conditions prohibit the filing of such prior notice, in which case it shall be filed as soon as possible. The time for beginning maternity leave shall be when the employee, with the approval of such employee's doctor, deems such employee is no longer able to carry out the duties and responsibilities of her position. The time for termination of maternity leave shall be when the employee's doctor certifies that she is able to return to work. Maternity leave shall consist of the use of any accumulated sick and annual leave, at the expiration of which permanent-status career employees may apply to the city manager for leave without pay as set forth in section 62-231. Reemployment rights available to employees granted leave without pay shall apply to employees granted leave without pay because of pregnancy and childbirth. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-230. - Bereavement or funeral leave. (a) City employees will be allowed three days off with pay in the event of a death in the employee's immediate family, i.e., an employee's spouse, child, mother, father, brother, sister, mother-in-law, father-in-law or grandparent. (b) City employees will be allowed time off for a funeral, not to exceed four hours, for a death in the non-immediate family, including a grandparent-in-law, aunt, uncle, brother-in-law or sister-in-law. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000; Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 6-2-2011) Sec. 62-231. - Leave without pay. (a) Entitlement. When it is deemed in the best interest of the city government service, a permanent status career employee may be granted leave without pay for personal or other reasons, provided, such leave is recommended by the department head and approved by the city manager. Non-career employees shall not be eligible for grants of leave without pay. (b) Reasons for granting. The city manager may grant an employee up to 20 workdays off without pay when it is deemed to be in the best interest of the city. Valid reasons for the granting of leave without pay shall include, but are not limited to, illness of a member of the employee's household, educational or training enrichment, pregnancy, childbirth and military service. Any requests for leave without pay which exceed 20 workdays shall be approved by the mayor and board of aldermen. (c) Request. An application for leave without pay shall be submitted in writing in advance, and shall state the employee's reason for requesting such leave, and shall contain a statement that such employee intends to return to the city government service upon expiration of such leave, and that he agrees to the terms and conditions as outlined in this section. In emergency situations, when an employee does not have accrued leave and is unable to return to work as scheduled as a result of illness or emergency reasons, their department head may recommend approval of the granting of leave without pay without prior application by the employee, or the personnel officer may investigate and make such recommendations in the absence of the department head. (d) Temporarily filling of position. During an employee's approved leave of absence, their position may be filled by temporary appointment or substitution. At the expiration of the leave without pay, the employee, subject to subsection (e) of this section, shall be reinstated in his former position and the substitute employee returned to their former position without loss of status or benefits. (e) Right of employee. (1) Reinstatement to former position. Employees granted leave without pay not exceeding two calendar months shall be entitled to reinstatement in their former positions. For employees granted leave without pay exceeding two calendar months, every effort will be made to return the employee to his former position or a comparable position. Such employee shall be listed on reemployment lists in the same manner as employees who are laid off in good standing. (2) Continuity of service. Employees granted leave without pay shall not be considered to have effected a break in service, except as follows: a. In cases of leave without pay exceeding two calendar months, the effective date of an employee's merit increase shall be adjusted month for month for each month he is on leave without pay in excess of two months. b. In the case of a probational status employee, either from initial or promotional appointment, the effective date of the end of the probationary period shall be adjusted month for month for each month he is on leave without pay. c. For purposes of retirement benefits for eligible employees, breaks in service shall be as defined in the retirement ordinance. d.
