Continuation of insurance benefits for eligible employees during the time the employee is on leave without pay shall be in accordance with the provisions of employee group insurance contracts. If there are no provisions, then the employee shall be responsible to pay 100 percent of the costs after such employee is on leave after two months. e. Employees granted leave without pay under this section shall not accrue sick and annual leave while in leave status. However, any sick leave accrued at the time leave is granted shall be continued upon the employee's return to duty. Any employee who fails to return to duty and whose employment is terminated shall forfeit any sick leave that such employee has accumulated. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000; Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 6-2-2011) Secs. 62-232—62-260. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - EMPLOYEE DEVELOPMENT
Sec. 62-261. - Uniforms; equipment. Uniforms for police department employees, and such other employees as the city manager may authorize, may be furnished by the city government. Equipment deemed essential to job performance may also be furnished, if authorized by the city manager. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-262. - In-service training. The city manager shall be responsible for fostering and promoting in-service training of employees for the purpose of improving the quality of service and assisting employees in preparing themselves for advancement. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-263. - Educational assistance program. (a) Tuition reimbursement. (1) General purpose. To develop a better educated and more highly skilled city workforce. (2) Statement of policy. It is the policy of the city to provide tuition assistance benefits to help employees pay for the cost of courses related to their job (upon the availability of funds and in accordance with the guidelines as shown below). Executive MBA and PHD programs are not covered under this policy. (3) Procedures. Eligibility. Any full-time city employee who has been employed by the city in a regular full time capacity for at least 12 consecutive months of continuous employment on a regular, full-time basis prior to the beginning of the course for which educational assistance is sought may apply to participate in the program. This policy does not apply to contract, temporary or part-time employees. Initial approval of a course of study does not obligate the city to future/continued approval of courses in that course of study. Approvals are only valid for the course and quarter / semester given. Before an employee requests reimbursement through the city's educational assistance program, an employee must apply for educational scholarships (ie. Georgia Hope Scholarship, GI Bill) or submit evidence that the employee is not eligible to receive said educational scholarships. (4) Types of courses. The following courses are reimbursable depending upon the availability of city funds and approval by the respective department head and city manager: a. Courses that are part of a structured program to assist the employee in attaining his or her high school diploma or equivalent (GED); b. Technical or skills courses offered through accredited technical schools if an employee's department head and the city manager determine that the courses relate to the employee's current work assignment or potential promotional opportunities; c. Undergraduate and graduate courses offered through accredited colleges or universities if an employee's department head and the city manager determine that the courses relate to the employee's current work assignments or potential promotional opportunities; d. Courses that are part of an approved degree-related program which is related to the employee's current job or future advancement opportunities within the city. (5) Scheduling of courses. Employees are expected to attend courses on their own time, unless directed by their supervisors or department head to do otherwise. (In such cases, the city manager, mayor and board of aldermen shall be notified by the department head). (6) Amount of reimbursement. Tuition reimbursement will be provided for no more than two courses per academic term per eligible employee. Total reimbursement for assistance will be limited to a maximum of $1,500.00 per eligible employee per fiscal year. Tuition, registration fees and required lab fees will be reimbursed according to the following schedule: Grade Received Reimbursement Percentage A or P (for "Pass/Fail" courses) 60% B 50% C 25% D 0% F, W (withdraw), W/F (withdraw failing) 0% Inc. (Incomplete) 0%
Reimbursement applies only to tuition, registration fees and required lab fees. The city will not reimburse employees for books, activity fees, parking, meals or other related expenses. Employees who receive other forms of financial aid, such as private scholarships or grants, assistance from a government agency, and/or veterans' benefits will be reimbursed only for the difference between reimbursable expenses and the aid received from elsewhere (times the applicable percentage above). Employees who receive other assistance must provide evidence of such assistance to their department head and the city manager. At the request of the department head or the city manager, the employee may be required to provide documentation (letter) from the institution they are attending verifying receipt/non-receipt of funding from alternative sources. (7) Effect of employment termination. To be reimbursed, employees must still be employed by the city when evidence of satisfactory course completion is submitted to the city. (8) Submission of request. Before registering for a course/degree program, an employee must submit a request for tuition reimbursement to his or her immediate supervisor prior to the start of the course. The employee must attach a copy of the course description from the course catalog or other publication along with the cost of said course. The employee and immediate supervisor will discuss the relevance of the course(s) to the employee's position and/or future goals with the city before submitting the request to the respective department head. Employees enrolled in a degree program at an accredited college or university must be able to demonstrate how the degree will apply to their position. (9) Department head's role. The department head will review the request and either approve or deny the request in writing and sign the employee's memorandum request for reimbursement. If the document is approved by the department head, the documents will then be forwarded to the city manager for approval/denial. (10) City manager's role. The city manager will review the request and decide whether or not the course fulfills the requirements of the policy and whether or not adequate funds are available. He or she will either approve or deny the request and sign it. At this point, the original request will be returned to the respective department head who will notify the employee of the decision. Another copy will be kept in the employee's personnel file. (11) Registration. The employee may register for the course once the application is approved. The city is not responsible for any costs an employee may incur unless they have specific written approval from the city manager. (12) Evidence of satisfactory completion. Upon the completion of the approve course(s), the employee is required to submit certified transcripts of his or her grade(s) and cancelled check(s) or receipts for the approved course(s) to the department head. These documents must be attached to the original "request for tuition reimbursement" document. These documents should be submitted within 30 days of completing the course(s) to the department head. Failure by the employee to submit said documents within 30 days of completing the course may result in non-reimbursement for the course(s) attended. (13) Authorization and payment. The department head and/or city manager (as applicable to amount requested reimbursed) will authorize disbursement to the employee (provided all applicable prior approval have been met and criteria adhered to). (14) Reimbursement of city costs if employee resigns. If an employee who has received funds through the city's educational assistance program for tuition reimbursement voluntarily leaves the city's employ within one year of receiving these funds, he/she will be required to reimburse the entire amount to the city. The city will be authorized by the employee to collect from him or her, either directly or by payroll deduction, the amount received during the previous year by the employee for educational assistance. (b) Incentive proficiency pay. (1) General purpose. To encourage job-related higher education and professional development and to provide an incentive to city employees for broadening their educational background in order to become more proficient and professional in the performance of their perspective city jobs. (2) Statement of policy. It is the policy of the city to provide incentive pay to full-time employees who, during their employment with the city, complete an approved degree or bona fide certification program which is directly applicable to the respective position with the city. (3) Eligibility. All regular-status, full-time employees are eligible to participate in the incentive proficiency pay (also known as incentive pro pay) program upon completion of an approved degree or certification program. (4) Examples of degree, diploma and/or certification programs. The following degrees will make an employee eligible for incentive pro pay is the degree program is directly applicable to the employee's position with the city (as determined by the department head and the city manager) and is from an accredited college or university: • Associate's degree. • Bachelor's degree. • Master's degree. Completion of a work-related diploma program from an accredited vocational-technical or other educational institution will also make an employee eligible for incentive pro pay if such a program can be successfully compared to a degree program at the Associate's level (as determined by the department head and the city manager). In addition, certain certification programs may make an employee eligible for incentive pro pay if the certification program is directly applicable to the employee's position with the city (as determined by the department head and the city manager). For the purposes of this policy, a certification program shall consist of a combination of the following: minimum of 100 hours training; or a required number of years experience within the profession; and a required educational level; and a required body of knowledge. Furthermore, certification is a voluntary action by a professional group to establish a system to grant recognition to professionals who have met a stated level of training and/or work experience. Certifications differ from certificate programs because certifications, by definition, include an experience component. Certificate programs, on the other hand, award certificates once a course of study has been completed and do not require previous work experience. (5) Incentive amount. Upon completion of an approved degree, diploma or certification program, a city employee will be awarded one of the following based upon circumstances and the decision of the city manager. a. A one-time bonus as a percentage of his/her current rate of pay (annualized) as follows: Certifications 2% Associates Degree 2% Bachelors Degree 3% Masters Degree 6%
Note: If an employee obtains a Bachelor's Degree without obtaining an Associates Degree, then the bonus amount is five percent. Furthermore, the bonus award is limited to one program per calendar year. b. A promotion to a different job classification and a raise. (6) Evidence of completion. Upon completion of an approved degree or certification program, the city employee is required to submit evidence of completion to his or her department head. After review and approval, the department head will submit all documents and a letter requesting the incentive pro pay to the personnel administrator and the city manager for approval and processing. (7) Effective date. Requests for incentive pro pay must be received by the city manager within 30 days of when the degree or certification was awarded. (8) Reimbursement. If an employee who has received an incentive pro pay bonus voluntarily leaves the city's employ within two years of receiving this bonus, he/she will be required to reimburse the entire amount to the city. (9) Exclusions. The incentive pro pay program is not intended to be used to reward employees who have participated in various short-term workshops, seminars or programs while employed by the city and will only be awarded to employees who have completed a bona fie degree, diploma or certification program. An approved list of certification programs will be maintained by the personnel administrator. City employees who must complete mandated training in order to successfully complete their working test period (for example, POST requirements) are not eligible for incentive pro pay for completing mandated training. (Instead, such employees are eligible to receive a merit increase at the conclusion of the working-test period.) The incentive pay program is not intended to be used by employees for degrees/certifications they received before they began their employment with the city or before the effective date of this program. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000; Ord. No. 2004-17, 4-15-2004) Sec. 62-264. - Insurance benefits. Provisions for group insurance and group medical coverage for city government employees shall be as outlined in existing group contracts and plans, or as such contracts and plans may be amended. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-265. - Retirement. Provisions for a retirement system for city government employees shall be as outlined in a retirement ordinance passed or amended by the board of aldermen. Nothing in this chapter, or the ordinance from which this chapter is adopted, shall affect any such ordinance, and all such ordinances are recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if they were set out at length in this section. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-266. - For employees hired on or after September 1, 2016, major medical insurance benefits for retired employees. When a permanent full time career employee retires from the City of Acworth, and if they have been employed a minimum of 30 full time continuous years with the city, and they have attained their 60th birthday while employed full time by the city, they will be eligible to purchase single coverage medical insurance under the then current city medical insurance plan until they become Medicare eligible. Said employee shall pay for said medical insurance at the same rate as then currently employed permanent full time career employees pay for medical insurance and said rate may be adjusted by the mayor and board of aldermen. Should said employee choose not to participate in Medicare, their eligibility for medical insurance under the city plan will cease on the date they would otherwise become eligible for Medicare coverage. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000; Ord. No. 2016-32, § 1, 8-18-2016) Sec. 62-267. - For employees hired prior to September 1, 2016, major medical insurance benefits for retired employees. (a) The city shall, at its expense, provide major medical insurance, equivalent to that provided to permanent full-time employees of the city, for all employees who retire from employment with the city at or after attaining 60 years of age, for the remainder of such retired employee's life, provided, such employee's age, plus completed years of service in the employment with the city, at the time of such employee's retirement, is equal to or greater than 85. (b) The following rules shall apply with regard to the city's payment of the cost of major medical insurance, equivalent to that which is provided to spouses of permanent full-time employees of the city, for the spouse of a retired employee, for the remainder of such spouse's life: (1) The city shall pay for 100 percent of the cost of such insurance if the employee retires after having completed 30 years of service with the city; (2) The city shall pay for 75 percent of the cost of such insurance if the employee retires after having completed 25 years of service with the city; (3) The city shall pay for 50 percent of the cost of such insurance if the employee retires after having completed 20 years of service with the city; and (4) The spouse of an employee who retires before completing 20 years of service with the city shall not be entitled to be provided with any major medical insurance by the city or at the city's cost. (Ord. No. 2016-32, § 1, 8-18-2016) Secs. 62-268—62-300. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - RECORDS; REPORTS
Sec. 62-301. - Records open to public. All personnel records of the city, except examinations, employee performance reports, personnel histories and such other records as may be specified in this article or by action of the city manager as confidential shall be public records and shall be open for public inspection during office hours and reasonable times in accordance with such procedures as the personnel officer may prescribe. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-302. - Establishment; retention of records. There shall be established and maintained such personnel records as the city manager deems necessary for the administration of the merit system of the city. The personnel officer, with the approval of the city manager, shall prescribe the form and scope of the personnel records. When not in conflict with state or federal laws, the city manager shall determine the time limit that personnel records shall be kept on file, and shall determine the final disposition of such records. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-303. - Employee performance reports. Immediate supervisors shall initiate employee performance reports in such form and at such times as directed by the city manager. Performance reports shall be reviewed and approved by the department head and the city manager prior to the granting of merit increases. Reports of substandard performance shall be reviewed and signed by affected employees prior to the submission of such reports to the city manager. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-304. - Safety restraints. (a) Required. All city employees and passengers shall be required, while occupying a city vehicle on city business or their personal vehicle, while on city business, to wear a seat belt and shoulder harness, and if the vehicle occupied is not equipped with a seat belt and shoulder harness, the city employees and passengers occupying the vehicle shall wear the safety equipment provided. This shall include employees operating construction equipment that is equipped with seatbelts and a rollover protection device. It shall be the city employee's responsibility to make sure that all passengers wear the appropriate safety restraint while occupying a city vehicle. (b) Violation; disciplinary action. Any city employee found in violation of subsection (a) of this section shall be subject to disciplinary action. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000; Ord. No. 2012-25, § 1, 12-6-2012) Secs. 62-305—62-340. - Reserved. ARTICLE IX. - DRUG-FREE WORKPLACE
Sec. 62-341. - Policy. It shall be the policy of the city that the unlawful manufacture, distribution, dispensation, possession or use of any drugs, including alcohol, or any controlled substance as defined by state law is prohibited in the workplace or in the course of employment by all persons employed by the city. (Ord. No. 2000-26, 8-3-2000) Sec. 62-342. - Drug testing. (a) Findings. (1) The city has a public trust to provide a variety of services to the city. An efficient and productive work force is vital to carry out such trust. The public has a reasonable right to expect persons employed by the city to perform their duties free from the effects of drugs, including alcohol. (2) The city has an obligation to ensure public safety through the actions of its employees. Furthermore, employees of the city have a reasonable right to work in a safe environment, free from the effects of drug use. The city has a reasonable right to expect its employees to report for work fit for duty, free from the effects of drug use. (3) The city recognizes that an employee's physical condition affects job performance, and that drug abuse ranks as one of the major health problems in society. It is the intent of this section to express the city's viewpoint on drug usage exhibited by behavioral and medical disorders, to encourage an enlightened viewpoint towards such disorders and to provide guidelines for consistent handling of situations arising from such disorders. (b) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Controlled substance means any of those substances listed under O.C.G.A. as a controlled substance. The term "controlled substance" shall include marijuana and cocaine. Drug and alcohol testing means urinalysis or breath analysis. Illegal drugs mean drugs for which the possession, use, sale or distribution is unlawful pursuant to state or federal laws or regulation. The term "illegal drugs" shall include drugs that are not legally obtainable and drugs that are legally obtainable but have been obtained illegally. Intoxicating substance means any substance that produces changes in a person's physical, mental or emotional state or behavior, including, but not limited to glue, paint thinner, etc. Possession means having controlled substances that are not obtained either directly from a doctor or pharmacist using a valid prescription, or having controlled substances, the possession or use of which is unlawful pursuant to state or federal laws or regulations, including a person having such substances in his body. Reportable incident means any personal injury or property damage involving a city employee which occurs on or off city property during assigned work hours, or that occurs at a time an employee is using a city vehicle. Under the influence of alcohol means, as a result of the consumption of alcohol, an employee's or applicant's ability to perform his job is impaired to an appreciable degree. For the purposes of this definition, a blood alcohol level of 0.04 percent alcohol in the blood by weight shall conclusively establish that an employee is under the influence. However, an employee with a blood alcohol level of less than 0.04 percent alcohol in the blood by weight may also be considered to be under the influence of alcohol if job performance is impaired to any appreciable degree. Under the influence of drugs or other intoxicating substances means, as a result of the consumption, inhalation or injection of drugs or any other intoxicating substance, an employee's job performance is impaired to an appreciable degree, or if a drug screen is positive for any illegal drugs. (c) Rules and regulations. (1) The city is concerned with situations where use of alcohol and intoxicating substances are detrimental to the public trust or the safety of employees or citizens. The city is committed to the rehabilitation of employees who abused alcohol by allowing continued employment for those employees who are voluntarily enrolled in an alcohol rehabilitation program at such employee's expense. (2) Early recognition and treatment of alcohol problems is important for successful rehabilitation to improve job performance and reduce personal, family and social disruption. Employees who participate in a program for the purpose of treating alcoholism may do so without jeopardizing their employment with the city, provided, they stop all involvement with alcohol and, provided, the employee enrolls and satisfactorily participates in an alcohol abuse assistance or rehabilitation program approved for such purposes by a federal, state or local health, law enforcement or other such governmental agency at the employee's own expense. Continued employment is also predicated on the employee not violating the conditions set forth in this section more than one time. (3) To implement the policy set forth in this section, the following rules are established as conditions of employment with the city: a. Conditions of employment. It shall be the policy of the city that the unlawful manufacture, distribution, dispensation, possession or use of any drugs, including alcohol, or any illegal drug or controlled substance, as defined by state law, is prohibited in the work place or in the course of employment by all persons employed by the city. b. Disciplinary action. 1. As a condition of employment by the city, all employees shall abide by the terms set forth in this section. Any failure of an employee to abide by the conditions of employment set forth in this section shall constitute grounds for disciplinary action by the city, including termination of employment. 2. Any employee convicted of violating a criminal drug statute while in the course of his employment with the city shall notify the city manager within five days after such conviction. 3. Any employee convicted of violating a criminal drug statute while in the course of his employment with the city shall be terminated. c. Investigation. Whenever a department head has reasonable cause, including, but not limited to, slurred speech; odor of breath; bloodshot or glassy eyes; unsteady feet or a staggered gait; boisterous, vulgar, loud, profane or unbecoming language; and behavior that is uncharacteristic of that particular employee, or when any city employee is involved in a reportable incident that results in injury to person or property, such employee shall be subject to an investigation with the approval of the city manager or his designee. Such employee will be directed to undergo drug or alcohol detection tests. The employee shall be transported to a medical or police department facility for drug and alcohol testing. All testing will be at the city's expense. Employees who are tested pursuant to this subsection shall be furnished with a copy of the test results upon the request of the employee. The refusal by the employee to submit to such testing shall be cause for disciplinary action, including dismissal. d. Preemployment testing. Whenever an individual applies for employment with the city, and in order to be considered for such employment, the applicant shall be required to undergo drug and alcohol testing. All drug and alcohol testing will be at the city's expense, and the applicant tested pursuant to this subsection shall be furnished with a copy of his test results upon the request of the employee. The refusal of an applicant to submit to such testing shall remove the applicant from being considered for employment by the city. The city will not hire any applicant who tests positive on a detection test for illegal drugs or alcohol. Such persons will be prohibited from employment with the city for a period of one year, unless they provide certified documentation of successful completion of a substance abuse rehabilitation program. Applicants who have completed a substance abuse rehabilitation program will be subject to drug screening prior to being employed. e. Random testing. The city shall be authorized to conduct random drug testing of city employees who are classified in safety-sensitive positions. Such testing will be at the city's expense, and any employee tested pursuant to this subsection shall be furnished with a copy of his test results upon the request of such employee. The refusal by the employee to submit to such testing shall be cause for disciplinary action, including dismissal. The positions classified as safety-sensitive shall be as follows: 1. Peace officers. 2. Jailers. 3. Police dispatchers. 4. Public works foreman. 5. Public works equipment operators. 6. Power linemen (all levels). 7. Power tree trimmer (all levels). 8. Power equipment operator. 9. CableNET technicians. 10. Department heads of all city departments. f. Termination for positive test result. If any employee's alcohol test performed pursuant to this section is positive, the employee's employment with the city shall be terminated, or at the option of the city, the employee shall be required to satisfactorily participate in an alcohol abuse assistance or rehabilitation program approved for such purposes by a federal, state or local health, law enforcement or other governmental agency. An employee's participation in such alcohol abuse assistance rehabilitation program shall be at the employee's own expense, and shall be a condition of continued employment with the city. If any employee's drug test performed pursuant to this section is positive for illegal drugs, the employee's employment with the city shall be terminated with no right of appeal. g. Inspection of premises. Whenever the city manager or his designee has reasonable cause to believe that there is alcohol, illegal drugs or any controlled substance, as defined by state law, present in or upon any real property owned or occupied by the city, or in any personal property owned or possessed by the city, the city manager or his designee shall have the right to inspect the premises, including an employee's desk, clothing, purse, personal belongings or person, in order to investigate potential misconduct relevant to the performance of an employee's duties, and to prevent damage in the future to the city's ability to discharge its duties and responsibilities. h. Termination. If drugs, alcohol or any controlled substance are found on an employee, in his desk or in his personal belongings, such employee's employment with the city shall be terminated. (Ord. Sec. 62-391. - Purpose. The purpose of this issuance is to establish the City of Acworth Internet and Electronic Mail Acceptable Use Policy for employee use of information technology (IT) resources in the City of Acworth (city). This policy applies to all city IT resources regardless of location (i.e. office, home, field locations, etc.). (Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 3-11-2010) Sec. 62-392. - General principles. This statement sets forth the policy of the City of Acworth (city) with regard to access to and disclosure of electronic mail (e-mail) and other electronic records sent or received by employees, both internally and via the Internet. Internet and e-mail services are provided by the city to support open communications and exchange of information and the opportunity for collaborative government-related work. The city encourages the use of electronic communications by its agencies and employees. Although, access to information and information technology is essential to the missions of government agencies and their users, use of Internet and e-mail services is a revocable privilege. Conformance with acceptable use, as expressed in this policy statement, is required. City departments are expected to maintain and enforce this policy. (Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 3-11-2010) Sec. 62-393. - No privacy rights. All communication or information stored on or transmitted via the city's information system (system includes information technology, Internet access, voice mail, computer equipment, data, databases, files, and software) is the sole property of the city. Employees waive any expectation of privacy with respect to anything they create, store, send or receive in connection with their use of the system. City has the right, without creating any obligation to do so, to access, audit and monitor any communication or information employees create, store, send or receive in connection with their use of the system. Information obtained in the course of such access, auditing and monitoring of the system may be used or disclosed, by the city, at its sole discretion or election, and to third parties to comply with laws, regulations, court orders, subpoenas or other governmental procedures without notice to the employee. (Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 3-11-2010) Sec. 62-394. - Open Records Act. (a) All public departments are subject to the Open Records Act. All records, including computer based or generated information is in conjunction with this act. Therefore, users of the city's information systems should treat computer based information as they would written communications. All information on the city's computerized system is confidential. Such information may not be shared with other users internally or externally except through the procedures outlined in the Georgia Open Records Act. (b) Department heads will be responsible for determining what information is appropriate for dissemination via e-mail. (c) Permanence: Users shall exercise the same care in drafting e-mail that would be applied to any other written communication. E-mail is more permanent than paper communications and anything said in an e-mail may be discovered by an opponent in litigation. (d) Enforcement: All provisions of this policy are deemed rules of the city and violation of any could result in disciplinary action up to and including termination as per section 62-403) of the City Code. (Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 3-11-2010) Sec. 62-395. - Activities which may result in disciplinary action. (a) Visiting inappropriate websites (erotica, hate groups, etc.). (b) Unauthorized attempts to break into any computer whether it belongs to the City of Acworth or other organization (cracking). (c) Sending or posting threatening messages. (d) Sending or posting racially and/or sexually harassing messages. (e) Sending or posting sexually suggestive or explicit messages. (f) Theft, or copy of electronic files without permission. (g) Sending or posting confidential information that is not part of your job requirement. (h) Refusing to cooperate with a reasonable security investigation. (i) Knowingly transmit viruses or other files that may cause harm to any city computer and/or network. (j) Knowingly transmit viruses or other files that may cause harm to another's computer or network. (k) Knowingly open e-mail or attachments that may endanger any city computer and/or network. (l) Knowingly open e-mail or attachments that may endanger another's computer or network. (m) Knowingly visit web sites that may endanger any city computer and/or network. (n) Knowingly visit web sites that may endanger another's computers of network. At a minimum, users of Internet and e-mail services provided by the city are expected to: (o) Be responsible for compliance with the provisions of this policy. Before Internet or outside e-mail services are granted, the employee must sign the attached release form signifying the employee's familiarity and acceptance of this policy statement. The burden of responsibility is on the user to abide by the acceptable and unacceptable uses, or prior to use, inquire about uses not cited. Compliance with applicable acceptance use restrictions is mandatory. (p) Use city provided Internet and e-mail services for city government-related activities and not for personal business. (q) Abide by the legal protection provided by copyright and license to programs and data. (r) Know and follow the generally accepted etiquette of the Internet. For example, use civil forms of communication when using e-mail and/or the Internet. (s) Avoid uses of the network that reflect poorly on a department and/or city. Statements in e-mail and/or the Internet should reflect the same language used in the presence of a department head and/or the city manager. (Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 3-11-2010) Sec. 62-396. - Specifically acceptable uses for the Internet and e-mail services. (a) Communication and information exchange directly related to the mission, charter, or work tasks of the city department. (b) Communication and exchange for professional development, to maintain currency of training or education, or to discuss issues related to the user's city research or programs. (c) Use in applying for or administering grants or contracts for the city's research or programs. (d) Use for advisory, standards, research, analysis, and professional society activities related to the user's city work tasks and duties. (e) For announcements of new city regulations, ordinances, procedures, policies, rules, services, programs, information, or activities. (f) Any other government administrative communications not requiring a high level of security. (g) Incidental and occasional use of e-mail for personal reasons (i.e. e-mailing a spouse from work). (Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 3-11-2010) Sec. 62-397. - Specifically unacceptable uses for the Internet and e-mail services. (a) Use the Internet and/or e-mail for any purpose that violates a federal, state, or local law. (b) Use for any for-profit activities unless specific to the charter, mission, or duties of a city department and/or agency. (c) Use for purposes not directly related to the mission, charter, or work tasks of a city department during normal business hours. (d) Use for private business, including commercial advertising. (e) Use for access to and distribution of: (1) Patently offensive representations or descriptions of ultimate sexual acts, normal or perverted, actual or simulated or patently offensive representations or descriptions of masturbation, excretory functions, or lewd exhibition of the genitals; (2) Material sent or received in violation of the Protection of Children Against Sexual Exploitation Act of 1977, as amended, 18 U.S.C. 2252 except for law enforcement agents pursuing a lawful investigation of infringement of 18 U.S.C.2252 or other similar laws. (f) Use for access to and distribution of computer games that have no bearing on the department and/or agency's mission. Some games that help teach, illustrate, train, or simulate agency-related issues may be acceptable. (g) Use of city provided Internet and/or e-mail services so as to interfere with or disrupt network users, services, or equipment. (h) Intentionally seeking information on, obtaining copies of, or modifying files and other data that are confidential under federal, state, or local law, unless specifically authorized to do so once the legal conditions for release are satisfied. (i) No intentional copy is to be made of any software, electronic file, program or data using city provided Internet and/or e-mail services without a prior, good faith determination that such copying is, in fact, permissible. Any efforts to obtain permission should be adequately documented. Copyrighted materials include not only text, but also pictures, video, and audio. (j) Intentionally seeking information on, obtaining copies of, or modifying files or data belonging to others without authorization of the file owner. Seeking passwords of others or the exchange of passwords is specifically prohibited. (k) Users intentionally representing themselves electronically as others, either on the city internal network or elsewhere on the Internet unless specifically authorized to do so by those users. Users shall not circumvent established policies defining eligibility for access to information or systems. (l) Intentionally developing programs designed to harass other users or infiltrate a computer or computing system and/or damage or alter the software components of same. (m) Use for fund raising or public relations activities not specifically related to city approved activities. The city manager must approve all city fundraising. (n) The City of Acworth Personnel Manual restricts political activities of city employees. This includes use of computer equipment and resources. (o) Other uses deemed to be inappropriate by the city manager. (Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 3-11-2010) Sec. 62-398. - Additional guidelines. (a) External Internet service providers: The IT department provides Internet access to city employees for business use. No other external Internet service providers' software (including dial up networking applets) shall be installed on any city computer without expressed permission of the IT department. (b) Computer viruses on downloaded software: Any software obtained from outside the city government shall be virus checked prior to use. Any virus outbreaks or virus-like activity on the city network will be promptly reported to the IT director and/or his/her designee. (c) Use by contractors: Contractors and other non-city employees may be granted access to city provided Internet services at the discretion of the city manager and IT director. Acceptable use by contractors and other non-city employees, contracted with the city, is the responsibility of the contracting department head. Department heads are expected to provide such individuals who use city Internet and/or e-mail services with this policy. (d) Passwords: Use passwords associated with the city's information system only on that system. When setting up an account at a different information system that will be accessed using the Internet, choose a password that is different from ones used for city information systems. (e) VPN (External Access): The city will provide some users access to the city network via virtual private network (VPN) access from home computers. Such access will be gained through a secured VPN appliance. When completing VPN access, users should always exit the VPN connection to help prevent potential breaches of security. (f) Shared computers (logoff): Some computers are shared among several users. Each user is responsible for activities occurring on the computer while they are logged into their individual account. It is imperative that each user log off on shared computers across the network at the end of their work period. (g) E-mail security: Unencrypted electronic mail sent or received outside any department and on the Internet cannot be expected to be secure. (h) Large file transfers and internet capacity: The Internet connection is a shared resource. While routine e-mail and file transfer activities won't impact other users much, large file transfers and intensive multimedia activities will impact the service levels of other users. (i) Disclaimers: Users shall avoid being drawn into discussions where disclaimers like "this represents my personal opinion and not that of my department or of the city" need to be used. When you are using Internet and/or e-mail services provided by the city, users need to remember that they are representing the city and shall act accordingly. Users may be held legally responsible for any litigious acts against the city resulting from statements made on the Internet or by via e-mail. (j) Retention: This policy shall comply in all respects with the Retention Schedules set forth by the State of Georgia Archives in accordance with O.C.G.A 50-18-99. Only essential files and e-mail should be saved. (k) Permanence: Users shall exercise the same care in drafting e-mail that would be applied to any other written communication. E-mail is more permanent than paper communications and anything said in e-mail may be discovered by an opponent in litigation. All e-mail communications shall follow the retention schedule as listed above. (l) Enforcement: All provisions of this policy are deemed rules of the city and violation of any could result in disciplinary action up to and including termination in accordance with the City of Acworth Personnel Ordinance/Manual. (Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 3-11-2010) Sec. 62-399. - Procedures. Each employee is responsible for compliance with the provisions of this policy. Before Internet or outside e-mail services are granted, the employee must sign the attached release form signifying the employee's familiarity and acceptance of this policy statement. When an instance of non-compliance with this policy is discovered or suspected, the agency shall proceed in accordance with departmental and city personnel policies. Complaints about inappropriate or offensive e-mail should be promptly reported to the immediate supervisor. Such reports shall be taken seriously by the supervisor and carefully investigated. Suspension of service to users may occur when deemed necessary to maintain the operation and integrity of the city's network. User accounts and password access may be withdrawn without notice if a user violates the acceptable use policy. Disciplinary action up to and including termination of employment may be imposed depending on the severity of the violation. Criminal or civil action against users may be initiated when laws are violated. (Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 3-11-2010) Sec. 62-401. - Social networking. (a) There are several ways the city can benefit from using external (public) social networks such as Facebook, MySpace, Meetup, YouTube, Flickr, Twitter, LinkedIn, Friendster, Digg, Reddit, Delicious, StumbleUpon, etc. (b) The following are examples of legitimate city usage of public social networks: (1) Create groups to support employee recruiting activities. (2) Create groups to educate and promote county activities to selected audiences. (3) Public outreach to communicate and deliver messages directly to our citizens. (4) Encourage citizen involvement, interaction and feedback on city services. (5) Provide leadership and public service announcements. (6) Create custom network applications for events, alerts or integrate with city's self service applications. (Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 3-11-2010) Sec. 62-402. - Social networking guidelines. (a) Access and/or use of public social networking sites will be granted only at the request of department heads, with the approval of the city manager. (b) Users will be limited to the resources to which they need access. (c) Users setting up official city social network accounts will use a valid city e-mail address. (d) Users setting up official city social networking site(s) will use official logo. (e) Information technology will establish user access to the applicable social network site(s), bypassing website filters if necessary. (f) It is the responsibility of users to ensure that unauthorized persons are not allowed to make changes to official city social networking sites. (g) City social networking sites will be controlled by a secure username and password. (h) Each department is responsible for maintaining the user identifications and passwords for each site including maintaining the site on a regular basis. (i) Creation of "groups" within the social network to support city functions is allowed. However, each department agrees that they will regularly monitor and moderate group activity. (Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 3-11-2010) Sec. 62-403. - Other guidelines. Employees of the City of Acworth who maintain personal websites, social network sites, blog accounts, twitter accounts, and other similar sites should always be mindful that they represent the city. Acts during or outside duty hours that are incompatible with public service of the city are grounds for disciplinary review. Specific departments, such as the police department may have stricter guidelines set forth in internal policies. (Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 3-11-2010) Sec. 62-404. - Monitoring, compliance, and disciplinary action. The city has the capability and the authority to evaluate the performance and use of its IT resources and will routinely monitor their use. Individuals who abuse these resources, knowingly interfere with the operation of IT systems, or otherwise fail to comply with the provisions of this policy are subject to disciplinary action as set forth in the personnel ordinance, and possible loss or suspension of associated IT privileges. (Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 3-11-2010) Secs. 62-405—62-424. - Reserved. ARTICLE XI. - SEXUAL HARASSMENT OR CONDUCT[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, adopted April 2, 2009, set out provisions intended for use as art. I, §§ 62-15—62-19. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as art. XI, §§ 62-425—62-429.
Sec. 62-425. - Policy. (a) Sexual harassment is a form of employee misconduct which undermines the integrity of the work environment. Sexual harassment is also a form of sex discrimination in violation of various federal and state civil rights laws. (b) It is the policy of the city to seek prevention of sexual harassment of its employees and applicants for employment. (Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, 4-2-2009) Sec. 62-426. - Rights and responsibilities. In order to preserve the rights of all employees to work in an environment free from sexual harassment and, also, to protect the legitimate privacy interests of innocent parties, the city will provide a method for the confidential resolution of sexual harassment complaints. All parties should, but are not required to exhaust the informal remedies described herein before they resort to the formal grievance procedure. (1) Supervisory responsibilities. Supervisors are responsible for maintaining a positive work environment, setting a good example for others and promptly investigating all complaints of sexual harassment to determine what, if any, remedial action may be warranted. In resolving sexual harassment complaints, supervisors should seek advice and guidance from the personnel administrator and cooperate fully with his/her efforts to resolve any complaints referred to the personnel administrator by other parties. Supervisors should strive first and foremost to prevent any recurrence of prohibited activities or retaliation against victims. (2) Aggrieved employee/applicant responsibilities. a. An aggrieved party should try to tell the aggressor directly that his/her behavior is unwelcome, harmful or offensive to the aggrieved party. Some offenders may be genuinely oblivious to the effect of their words or conduct on other people and would be willing to change if only they knew they were hurting or offending someone. Aggrieved parties are strongly encouraged to promptly report the incident to the offender's supervisor or department head, or alternatively to personnel (human resources), so as to minimize the risk of repeated incidents or retaliation by the aggressor. Although, supervisors and managers of the city are to take appropriate action when they have reason to suspect that harassment has occurred, employees should not assume that the city is aware of any problem. It is also the employee's responsibility to bring any complaint to the attention of the management of the city so that the problem may be resolved. b. Aggrieved parties should make reasonable, good faith efforts to resolve their complaints before they resort to the formal grievance process. However, failure to do so does not preclude resorting to the formal grievance procedure and/or disciplinary action or any other resolution by the appropriate manager as a result of such grievance. (3) Personnel administrator responsibilities. a. The personnel administrator shall facilitate the resolution of any complaints brought to his/her attention. Upon request, the personnel administrator will provide counseling and support to victims, supervisors and other involved parties. The personnel administrator shall serve as expert advisor to any supervisor who is part of the reviewing procedure in the formal grievance process. In this capacity, the administrator shall offer his/her best professional judgment as to whether certain allegations, if true, would constitute sexual harassment. b. The personnel administrator is responsible for providing training to city supervisors and managers on the subject of sexual harassment. The training should provide supervisors with current information on applicable laws, rules, regulations and procedures and provide techniques for the careful investigation and mediation of sexual harassment allegations. (Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, 4-2-2009) Sec. 62-427. - Definitions. [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] Sexual harassment includes, but is not limited to, unwelcome sexual advances, requests for sexual favors, or other verbal or physical conduct of a sexual nature where: (1) Submission to said conduct is made, either explicitly or implicitly, a term or condition of an individual's employment; or (2) Submission to or rejection of such conduct by an individual is used as the basis for employment or continued employment; or (3) Such conduct has the purpose or necessary effect of unreasonably interfering with an individual's work performance or creating a hostile, intimidating or offensive work environment; or (4) Such conduct or behavior was known by the aggressor to be unwelcome, harmful or offensive; or (5) A person of average sensibilities would clearly have understood that the behavior or conduct was unwelcome, harmful or offensive. Work environment is defined as any place where the business of the city is conducted in the name of the city or any department or division thereof. (Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, 4-2-2009) Sec. 62-428. - Resolution procedure. (a) Any employee or applicant for employment who, in good faith, believes that he may be a victim of sexual harassment should: (1) Immediately ask the alleged offender to stop doing the unwelcome, harmful or offensive conduct; and (2) Promptly contact the offending party's supervisor, department head or personnel administrator for support and guidance. Successful resolution efforts will be greatly facilitated by the timely reporting of complaints. (b) The supervisor of the alleged offender and department head will promptly investigate the complaint and if the complaint is founded, will take appropriate disciplinary action up to and including termination of employment. (c) The aggrieved party may also file a formal grievance as outlined in art. V, section 62-184 of the personnel ordinance. Time limits for filing a formal grievance of sexual harassment are extended to 30 calendar days from the date of a specific alleged occurrence. If the alleged issue relates to on-going conditions, the employee may file a written grievance at any time. (d) The personnel administrator will advise all supervisors and the city manager regarding the substance of the formal charges. (e) If a complaint is filed against the personnel administrator, the city manager or his/her designee shall fulfill the role ascribed to the personnel administrator. (Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, 4-2-2009) Sec. 62-429. - Remedial action. (a) In determining what remedial action may be appropriate, supervisors should consider the extent to which the offender knew or reasonably should have known that his/her conduct was unwelcome, harmful or offensive. Any person who: (1) Commits sexual harassment; or (2) Shirks his/her investigatory or supervisory responsibilities; or (3) Provides false witness against another; shall be subject to appropriate disciplinary action including, but not limited to, referral to professional counseling at the offending party's expense; oral and written reprimands, performance probation, suspension or termination. (b) Some coercive behavior, such as threats or promises that employment reprisals or awards will follow the refusal or granting of sexual favors, constitutes gross misconduct and may provide just cause of immediate termination. (Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, 4-2-2009)

div.head: Chapter 66 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Any zoning ordinance saved from repeal, § 1-6(10); administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; flood prevention and drainage, ch. 50; nuisances, ch. 52; streets and sidewalks, ch. 82; utilities, ch. 94; vegetation, ch. 98; subdivisions and development regulations, app. A. State Law reference— Coordinated and comprehensive planning by counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 66-1. - Zoning application fees. Fees for applications under any provision of the city's zoning ordinance shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. Secs. 66-2—66-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Charter reference— Powers of city relating to planning and zoning, § 1.13(15). Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2.
Sec. 66-31. - Created; purposes. In order to guide and accomplish a coordinated and harmonious development of the city that will, in accordance with existing and future needs, best promote the public health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and the general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development, a planning commission is created. (Code 1983, § 15-16) Sec. 66-32. - Membership. The planning commission shall consist of not more than nine members, who shall be residents of the city, appointed by the mayor and board of aldermen. The terms of the members shall be for four years, except that the first members shall be appointed for terms concurrent with the present term of office of the board of aldermen. Any vacancy in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor and board of aldermen, who shall also have the authority to remove any member for cause, on written charges, after a public hearing. All members shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. (Code 1983, § 15-17) State Law reference— Buildings and housing, O.C.G.A. tit. 8; permit to disturb burial place in course of land development, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-6; development and redevelopment generally, O.C.G.A. tit. 36, ch. 61 et seq.; state department of community affairs, O.C.G.A. § 50-8-1 et seq.; state office of planning and budget, O.C.G.A. § 45-12-70 et seq. Sec. 66-33. - Organization; rules; staff; finances. (a) The planning commission shall elect its chairman from among its members. The term of the chairman shall be for one year with eligibility for reelection. The planning commission shall appoint a secretary, who may be an officer or employee of the city. The planning commission shall make its own rules of procedure and determine its time of meeting. All meetings of the planning commission at which official action is taken shall be open to the public as provided by law, and all records of the planning commission shall be a public record. (b) The planning commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work and may contract with agencies of the state and city planners and other consultants for such services as it may require. The expenditures of the planning commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for the purpose by the mayor and board of aldermen. (Code 1983, § 15-18) State Law reference— Public meetings, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1 et seq. Sec. 66-34. - Powers and duties. The planning commission shall have those powers, duties and responsibilities set forth in the city's zoning ordinance and any other ordinances of the city that delegate powers, duties or responsibilities to the commission. (Code 1983, § 15-19; Ord. No. 92-010, § 1(q), 4-2-1992) Secs. 66-35—66-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - HISTORIC PRESERVATION[3] Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Georgia Register of Historic Places, O.C.G.A. § 12-3-50.2; grants to municipal corporations for repairs on facilities of historical value, O.C.G.A. § 36-40-1; Georgia Historic Preservation Act, O.C.G.A. § 44-10-20 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 66-71. - Purpose. In support and furtherance of its findings and determination that the unique historical, cultural and aesthetic heritage of the city is among its most valued and important assets and that the careful consideration of this heritage is essential to the promotion of the health, prosperity and general welfare of the people and the city; in order to further stimulate and encourage revitalization of the business districts and historical neighborhoods and to protect and enhance local historical and aesthetic areas and thereby promote and stimulate business; in order to enhance the opportunities for federal and state tax benefits under the relevant provisions of federal and state law; and in order to provide for the designation, protection, preservation and rehabilitation of historic landmarks and historic districts and to participate in federal and state programs to do the same, the mayor and board of aldermen declare it to be the purpose and intent of this article to establish a uniform procedure for the use in providing for the protection, enhancement, perpetuation and use of places, districts, sites, buildings, structures, objects, landscape features and works of art having a special historical, cultural or aesthetic interest or value, in accordance with the provisions of this article. (Code 1983, § 15-31) Sec. 66-72. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Certificate of appropriateness means a document approving a proposal to make a material change in the appearance of a designated historic property or landmark or of a structure, site, object or work of art located within a designated historic district, which document must be obtained from the historic preservation commission before such material change may be undertaken. A certificate of appropriateness need not be obtained respecting exterior paint colors. Commission means the historic preservation commission created by this article. Designation means a decision by the mayor and board of aldermen to designate a landmark or district located in the city as a historic landmark or as a historic district, which thereafter prohibits all material changes in appearance of such landmark or within such district prior to the issuance of a certificate of appropriateness by the historic preservation commission. Exterior architectural features means the architectural style, general design and general arrangement of the exterior of a building or other structure, including but not limited to, the kind or texture of the building material and the type and style of all windows, doors, signs and other related appurtenant architectural fixtures, features, details or elements. Exterior environmental features means all those aspects of landscape or the development of the site which affect the historical character of the property. Historic district means a geographically definable area, urban or rural, that contains structures, sites, objects, works of art or a combination that: (1) Have special character or special historical or aesthetic interest or value; (2) Represent one or more periods or styles of architecture typical of one or more eras in the history of the city, county, state or region; and (3) Cause such area, by reason of such factors, to constitute a visibly perceptible section of the city. Historic property or landmark shall mean a structure, site or work of art, including the adjacent area necessary for its proper appreciation or use, deemed worthy of preservation by reason of its value to the city, the county, the state or the region for one or more of the following reasons: (1) It is an outstanding example of a structure representative of its era; (2) It is one of the few remaining examples of a past architectural style; (3) It is a place or structure associated with an event or person of historic or cultural significance to the city, county, state or region; or (4) It is a site of natural or aesthetic interest that is continuing to contribute to the cultural or historical development and heritage of the city, county, state or region. Material change in appearance means a change that will affect either the exterior architectural or environmental features of a historic landmark or any structure, site or work of art within a historic district, and may include any one or more of the following: (1) A reconstruction or alteration of the size, shape or facade of a historic property, including relocation of any doors or windows or removal or alteration of any architectural elements, features or details; (2) Demolition of a historic structure or property; (3) Commencement of excavation; (4) A change in the location of advertising visible from the public right-of-way on any historic property; (5) The erection, alteration, restoration, relocation or removal of any building or other structure within a designated historic district, including walls, fences, steps and pavements, or other appurtenant features, except exterior paint alterations. (Code 1983, § 15-32) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 66-73. - Penalty. Violations of any provision of this article shall be punished in the same manner as provided in section 1-11. (Code 1983, § 15-33) Sec. 66-74. - Maintenance of historic property. (a) Ordinary repair. Ordinary maintenance, repair or painting of any exterior architectural or environmental feature in or on a historic property to correct deterioration, decay or damage, or to sustain the existing form, and that does not involve a material change in design, material or outer appearance does not require a certificate of appropriateness. (b) Conformity to existing building codes. Nothing in this article shall be construed as to exempt property owners from complying with existing applicable city or other building codes, nor to prevent any property owner from making any use of his property not prohibited by this article or by other statutes, ordinances or regulations. (Code 1983, § 15-37) Sec. 66-75. - In rem review procedures. (a) Preliminary review. Upon receipt of notice regarding a hearing on action against an unsafe or unfit dwelling, building or structure from the city building official pursuant to section 18-74, the chairman or vice-chairman of the commission shall determine whether the subject property may have historic, cultural, architectural or aesthetic qualities worthy of further consideration by the commission as a whole. If the chairman or vice-chairman determines no such qualities appear to exist, he shall transmit a written communication so stating to the city building official prior to the date of the hearing described in the notice. If the chairman or vice-chairman determines that such qualities may exist, he shall convene a meeting of the full commission to be held prior to the date of the hearing described in the notice. (b) Full commission review. At any meeting of the full commission convened pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, the commission shall review the notice and other documents provided by the city building official and any other relevant documentation or evidence in order to determine the historic, cultural, architectural or aesthetic qualities of the property. In its review of these qualities, the commission shall utilize the criteria set forth in section 66-133(a). Following its review, the commission shall prepare written comments identifying the historic qualities of the property, if any, and shall make recommendations regarding preservation options for the property, as appropriate. If no historic qualities are identified, the commission shall so state in its comments. The commission shall transmit these written comments to the city building official prior to the hearing on the property conducted by the building official. (Ord. No. 97-010, 7-17-1997) Secs. 66-76—66-100. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2.
Sec. 66-101. - Created. There is created a commission whose title shall be the "Acworth Historic Preservation Commission." Commission members shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by vote of the board of aldermen. The commission will have authority in recommending landmark and historic district designation, and as otherwise set forth in this article. (Code 1983, § 15-34(a)) Sec. 66-102. - Commission position within city government. The commission shall be considered part of the planning functions of the city. (Code 1983, § 15-34(b)) Sec. 66-103. - Commission members; number; appointment; terms; compensation. The commission shall consist of three residents of the city and who shall have demonstrated an interest in the preservation of historic resources appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the board of aldermen. Members shall serve three-year terms. In order to achieve staggered terms, initial appointments shall be one member for one year, one member for two years and one member for three years, provided, however, that although members are appointed for specific terms, they may be removed earlier than the expiration of their terms at the pleasure of the mayor and the board of aldermen. Members shall not receive a salary, although they may be reimbursed for expenses if approved by the board of aldermen. (Code 1983, § 15-34(c); Ord. No. 91-001, 2-7-1991; Ord. No. 2007-07, § 1, 4-5-2007; Ord. No. 2010-27, § 1, 11-18-2010; Ord. No. 2016-08, § 1, 2-18-2016; Ord. No. 2016-14, § 1, 4-7-2016) Sec. 66-104. - Powers. The commission shall be authorized to: (1) Prepare and maintain an inventory of all property within the city limits having the potential for designation as historic properties; (2) Recommend to the mayor and board of aldermen specific places, districts, sites, buildings, structures or works of art to be designated by ordinance as historic properties or historic districts; (3) Review and grant or deny applications for certificates of appropriateness in accordance with the provisions of this article; (4) Recommend to the mayor and board of aldermen that the designation of any place, district, site, building, structure or work of art as a historic property or historic district be revoked or removed; (5) Restore or preserve any historic properties acquired by the city with the approval of the mayor and board of aldermen; (6) Promote the acquisition by the city of facade easements and conservation easements in accordance with the provisions of the "Facade and Conservation Easements Act of 1976" (O.C.G.A. § 44-10-1 et seq.); (7) Conduct educational programs on historic properties located within the city limits; (8) Make such investigations and studies of matters relating to historic preservation as the mayor and board of aldermen or the commission itself may deem necessary or appropriate for the purpose of preserving resources, including but not limited to review and comment on actions by the city against unsafe or unfit dwellings, buildings or structures pursuant to article III, chapter 18; (9) Seek out state and federal funds for historic preservation and outline a program for the mayor and board of aldermen concerning the most appropriate uses of any funds acquired; (10) Submit to the historic preservation section of the state department of natural resources a list of historic landmarks or historic districts proposed to be designated and a list of historic landmarks and historic districts designated; (11) Perform historic preservation activities as the official agency of the city historic preservation program, with consent from the mayor and board of aldermen; (12) Receive donations, grants, funds or gifts of historic properties, and acquire and sell historic properties, with the approval of the mayor and board of aldermen; the commission shall not obligate the mayor and board of aldermen in any respect, financially or otherwise, without prior consent of the mayor and board of aldermen; (13) Consult with historic preservation experts in the historic preservation section of the state department of natural resources or its successor and the Georgia Trust for Historic Preservation, Inc.; (14) Review and make comments to the state historic preservation office concerning the nomination of properties within the city limits to the National Register of Historic Places; (15) Employ persons, if necessary, to carry out the responsibilities of the commission with prior approval from the mayor and board of aldermen; and (16) Participate in private, state and federal historic preservation programs and, with the consent of the mayor and board of aldermen, enter into agreements to do so. (Code 1983, § 15-34(d); Ord. No. 97-010, 7-17-1997) Sec. 66-105. - Power to adopt rules of procedures. The commission shall adopt rules and standards not inconsistent with the provisions of this article for the transaction of its business and consideration of applications for designations and certificates of appropriateness, such as bylaws and design guidelines and criteria and shall provide for the time and place of regular meetings and for the calling of special meetings. The commission shall select such officers as it deems appropriate from among its members. The latest edition of Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, shall determine the order of business at all meetings. (Code 1983, § 15-34(e)) Sec. 66-106. - Conflict of interest. At any time the commission reviews any application involving any property in which a member of the commission has ownership or other vested interest, that member will be forbidden from presenting, voting on or discussing that application, other than answering direct questions. At no time shall a member be allowed to conduct personal business for financial gain as a result of the commission's activities or decisions; nor shall a member be allowed to use his position for the purpose of financial gain. (Code 1983, § 15-34(f)) Sec. 66-107. - Authority to receive funding from various sources. The commission shall have the authority to accept donations, provided such donations do not displace appropriated governmental funds. (Code 1983, § 15-34(g)) Sec. 66-108. - Records of commission meetings. A public record shall be kept of the commission's resolutions, proceedings and actions. (Code 1983, § 15-34(h)) Secs. 66-109—66-130. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - RECOMMENDATION AND DESIGNATION OF HISTORIC DISTRICTS AND LANDMARKS
Sec. 66-131. - Preliminary research by commission. (a) Commission's mandate to conduct a survey of local historical resources. The commission shall compile and collect information and conduct surveys of historic resources within the city. (b) Commission's power to recommend districts and landmarks to the mayor and board of aldermen for designation. The commission shall present to the mayor and board of aldermen its nominations for historic districts and historic landmarks. (c) Preparation of report on proposed designations. Prior to the commission's recommendation of a historic landmark or historic district to the mayor and board of aldermen for designation, the commission shall prepare formal reports, which shall also be used to educate the community and to provide a permanent record of the proposed designation, and shall consist of: (1) A physical description; (2) A statement of the historical, cultural, architectural and/or aesthetic significance; (3) A map showing district boundaries and classification (i.e., historic, nonhistoric, intrusion) of individual properties, or showing boundaries of individual historic properties; (4) A statement justifying district or individual property boundaries; and (5) Representative photographs, if necessary for clarification. This report will be submitted to the historic preservation section of the state department of natural resources and the mayor and board of aldermen. (Code 1983, § 15-35(a)) Sec. 66-132. - Designation of a historic district. (a) Criteria for selection of historic districts. A historic district is a geographically definable area that contains structures, sites, works of art or a combination that: (1) Have special character or special historic/aesthetic value or interest. (2) Represent one or more periods or styles of architecture typical of one or more eras in the history of the city. (3) Cause such an area, by reason of such factors, to constitute a visibly perceptible section of the city. (b) Boundaries of a historic district. Boundaries of a historic district shall be specified on the official zoning map of the city as a public record; these boundaries will be included in the separate ordinances designating local districts. Boundaries specified in legal notices shall coincide with the boundaries finally designated. (c) Evaluation of properties within historic districts. Individual properties within historic districts shall be classified as: (1) Historic (more than 50 years old). (2) Nonhistoric (less than 50 years old, yet does not detract from the district). (3) Intrusion (structures less than 50 years old that detract from the district). (d) Affirmation of existing zoning. This article does not repeal local zoning ordinances, which remain in full force and effect; designation of a landmark or historic district shall not repeal the city's zoning ordinances and other applicable ordinances and regulations, which shall remain in full force and effect. (Code 1983, § 15-35(b)) Sec. 66-133. - Designation of a landmark. (a) Criteria for selection of landmarks. A historic landmark is a building, structure, site, object or work of art, including the adjacent area necessary for its proper appreciation or use, deemed worthy of preservation by reason of value to the city, the state or local region for one or more of the following reasons: (1) It is an outstanding example of a structure representative of its era. (2) It is one of the few remaining examples of past architectural style. (3) It is a place or structure associated with an event or person of historic or cultural significance to the city, county, state or region. (4) It is a site of natural or aesthetic interest that is continuing to contribute to the cultural or historical development and heritage of the city, county, state or region. (b) Boundary description. Boundaries shall be clearly defined for landmarks on the official zoning map of the city as a public record. (Code 1983, § 15-35(c)) Sec. 66-134. - Requirements for adopting an ordinance for the designation of historic districts and historic landmarks. (a) Application for designation of historic district or landmark. Designations may be proposed by the mayor and board of aldermen, the commission, or: (1) For historic districts. A historical society, neighborhood association comprised of owners of properties within the proposed district or group of property owners owning property in the proposed district. (2) For historic landmarks. A historical society, or the property owner for whose property designation is sought. However, no property shall be designated a historic landmark or included in a historic district if the property owner objects to its designation or inclusion. (b) Required components of a designation ordinance. Any ordinance designating any property or district as historic shall: (1) List each property in a proposed historic district or describe the proposed individual historic property; (2) Set forth the names and mailing addresses of the owners and occupants of the designated properties; (3) Require that a certificate of appropriateness be obtained from the commission prior to any material change in appearance of the designated property; and (4) Require that the property or district be shown on the official zoning map of the city as a public record. (c) Required public hearings. The commission and the mayor and board of aldermen shall hold a joint public hearing on any proposed ordinance for the designation of any historic district or landmark.
